PREFACE
This code of the City of Nauvoo, as supplemented, contains ordinances up to and
including ordinance 2019-2, passed 7-9-2019.  Ordinances of the City adopted
after said ordinance supersede the provisions of this code to the extent that
they are in conflict or inconsistent therewith. Consult the City office in
order to ascertain whether any particular provision of the code has been
amended, superseded or repealed.
                     Sterling Codifiers
                     Cincinnati, Ohio
PENDING ORDINANCES
 
ADOPTING ORDINANCE
ORDINANCE NO. 1991-5
AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING THE CITY CODE OF NAUVOO, ILLINOIS
   WHEREAS, The City Council for the City of Nauvoo, Illinois has determined
that it would be in the best interest of the City to codify the Ordinances of
the City, and
   WHEREAS, The City Council for the City of Nauvoo, Illinois has had the City
Ordinances codified by Sterling Codifiers, Inc., has reviewed and revised the
draft copy and has now been furnished with a completed City Code for the City
of Nauvoo, Illinois, and
   WHEREAS, it is in the best interests of the City that the revised City Code
be adopted as the City Code of Nauvoo, Illinois.
   NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the City Council of Nauvoo, Illinois, an
Illinois municipal corporation, as follows:
   1.  From and after the date of passage of this Ordinance, the City Code of
Nauvoo, Illinois, an Illinois municipal corporation, prepared by Sterling
codifiers, Inc., contains a compilation of all Ordinances of a general nature
together with the changes made to said Ordinances, under the direction of the
governing body of the City, shall be accepted in all courts without question as
the Official Code and Law of the City as enacted by the Mayor and City Council.
   2.  There is hereby adopted, the method of perpetual codification, the
loose-leaf type of binding together with the continuous supplement service,
whereby each newly adopted Ordinance of a general and permanent nature
amending, altering, adding or deleting provisions of the Official City Code is
identified by the proper catchline and is inserted in the proper place in the
official copy, certified as to correctness and available for inspection at any
and all times that the office of the City Clerk is regularly open.
   3.  All Ordinances of a general nature included in this Official City Code
shall be considered as a continuation of said Ordinance provision and the fact
that some provisions have been deliberately eliminated by the governing body
shall not serve to cause any interruption in the continuous effectiveness of
Ordinances included in said Official City Code. All Ordinances of a special
nature such as tax levy ordinances, bond ordinances, franchises, vacating
ordinances and annexation ordinances shall continue in full force and effect
unless specifically repealed or amended by a provision of the Official City
Code. Such Ordinances are not intended to be included in the Official City
Code.
   4.  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to change or
amend by additions or deletions, any part or portion of the Official City Code,
or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or alter or tamper with such
Official City Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the
City to be misrepresented thereby.
   5.  All Ordinances or parts of Ordinances in conflict herewith, are, to the
extent of such conflict, hereby repealed.
   6.  This Ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and after its
passage and approval and publication as provided by law.
   Passed and adopted by the City Council of Nauvoo, Illinois, on the 14th day
of January, 1992.
   /s/    J. Dale Bruegger   
   Mayor         
ATTEST:
/s/  M. Jane Hamma   
      Clerk

CHAPTER 1
OFFICIAL CITY CODE
SECTION:
1-1-1: Title
1-1-2: Acceptance
1-1-3: Amendments
1-1-4: Code Alterations
1-1-1: TITLE:
Upon adoption by the city council, this code is hereby declared to be and shall
hereafter constitute the official city code of the city of Nauvoo. This code of
ordinances shall be known and cited as the NAUVOO CITY CODE, and it is hereby
published by authority of the council and shall be kept up to date as provided
in section
1-1-3  of this chapter. Any reference to the number of any section contained
herein shall be understood to refer to the position of the same number, its
appropriate chapter and title heading, and to the general penalty clause,
relating thereto, as well as to the section itself, when reference is made to
this code by title in any legal documents. (1989 Code)
1-1-2: ACCEPTANCE:
This code, as hereby presented in printed form, shall hereafter be received
without further proof in all courts and in all administrative tribunals of this
state as the ordinances of the city of general and permanent effect, except the
excluded ordinances enumerated in section
1-2-1 of this title. (1989 Code)
1-1-3: AMENDMENTS:
Any ordinance amending this code shall set forth the title, chapter and section
number of the section or sections to be amended, and this shall constitute
sufficient compliance with any statutory requirement pertaining to the
amendment or revision by ordinance of any part of this code. All such
amendments or revisions by ordinance shall be immediately forwarded to the
codifiers and the said ordinance material shall be prepared for insertion in
its proper place in each copy of this code. Each such replacement page shall be
properly identified and shall be inserted in each individual copy of this code.
(1989 Code)
1-1-4: CODE ALTERATIONS:
It shall be deemed unlawful for any person to alter, change, replace or deface
in any way any section or any page of this code in such a manner that the
meaning of any phrase or order may be changed or omitted. Replacement pages may
be inserted according to the official instructions when so authorized by the
city council. The city clerk shall see that the replacement pages are properly
inserted in the official copies maintained in the office of the clerk. Any
person having in his custody an official copy of this code shall make every
effort to maintain said code in an up to date and efficient manner. He shall
see to the immediate insertion of new or replacement pages when such are
delivered to him or made available to him through the office of the city clerk.
Said codebooks, while in actual possession of officials and other interested
persons, shall be and remain the property of the city and shall be returned to
the office of the clerk when directed so to do by order of the city council.
(1989 Code)
CHAPTER 2
SAVING CLAUSE
SECTION:
1-2-1: Repeal Of General Ordinances
1-2-2: Public Utility Ordinances
1-2-3: Court Proceedings
1-2-4: Severability Clause
1-2-1: REPEAL OF GENERAL ORDINANCES:
All general ordinances of the city passed prior to the adoption of this code
are hereby repealed, except such as are included in this code or are by
necessary implication herein reserved from repeal (subject to the saving
clauses contained in the following sections), and excluding the following
ordinances which are not hereby repealed: tax levy ordinances; appropriation
ordinances; ordinances relating to boundaries and annexations; franchise
ordinances and other ordinances granting special rights to persons or
corporations; contract ordinances and ordinances authorizing the execution of a
contract or the issuance of warrants; salary ordinances; ordinances
establishing, naming or vacating streets, alleys or other public places;
improvement ordinances; bond ordinances; ordinances relating to elections;
ordinances relating to the transfer or acceptance of real estate by or from the
city; and all special ordinances. (1989 Code)
1-2-2: PUBLIC UTILITY ORDINANCES:
No ordinance relating to railroad crossings with streets and other public ways,
or relating to the conduct, duties, service or rates of public utilities shall
be repealed by virtue of the adoption of this code or by virtue of the
preceding section, excepting as this code may contain provisions for such
matters, in which case this code shall be considered as amending such ordinance
or ordinances in respect to such provisions only. (1989 Code)
1-2-3: COURT PROCEEDINGS:
No new ordinance shall be construed or held to repeal a former ordinance
whether such former ordinance is expressly repealed or not, as to any offense
committed against such former ordinance or as to any act done, any penalty,
forfeiture or punishment so incurred, or any right accrued or claim arising
under the former ordinance, or in any way whatever to affect any such offense
or act so committed or so done, or any penalty, forfeiture or punishment so
incurred or any right accrued or claim arising before the new ordinance takes
effect, save only that the proceedings thereafter shall conform to the
ordinance in force at the time of such proceeding, so far as practicable. If
any penalty, forfeiture or punishment be mitigated by any provision of a new
ordinance, such provision may be, by consent of the party affected, applied to
any judgment announced after the new ordinance takes effect.
This section shall extend to all repeals, either by express words or
implication, whether the repeal is in the ordinance making any new provisions
upon the same subject or in any other ordinance.
Nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed as abating any action now
pending under or by virtue of any general ordinance of the city herein repealed
and the provisions of all general ordinances contained in this code shall be
deemed to be continuing provisions and not a new enactment of the same
provision; nor shall this chapter be deemed as discontinuing, abating,
modifying or altering any penalty accrued or to accrue, or as affecting the
liability of any person, firm or corporation, or as waiving any right of the
city under any ordinance or provision thereof in force at the time of the
adoption of this code. (1989 Code)
1-2-4: SEVERABILITY CLAUSE:
If any section, subsection, subdivision, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase
of this code or any part thereof is for any reason held to be unconstitutional
or invalid or ineffective by any court of competent jurisdiction, such decision
shall not affect the validity or effectiveness of the remaining portions of
this code, or any part thereof. The city council hereby declares that it would
have passed each section, subsection, subdivision, paragraph, sentence, clause
or phrase thereof irrespective of the fact that any one or more sections,
subsections, subdivisions, paragraphs, sentences, clauses or phrases be
declared unconstitutional, invalid or ineffective. (1989 Code)
CHAPTER 3
DEFINITIONS
SECTION:
1-3-1: Construction Of Words
1-3-2: Definitions, General
1-3-3: Catchlines
1-3-1: CONSTRUCTION OF WORDS:
Whenever any word in any section of this code importing the plural number is
used in describing or referring to any matters, parties or persons, any single
matter, party or person shall be deemed to be included, although distributive
words may not have been used. When any subject matter, party or person is
referred to in this code by words importing the singular number only, or the
masculine gender, several matters, parties or persons and females as well as
males and bodies corporate shall be deemed to be included; provided, that these
rules of construction shall not be applied to any section of this code which
contains any express provision excluding such construction or where the subject
matter or context may be repugnant thereto.
The word "ordinance" contained in the ordinances of the city has been changed
in the content of this code to "title", "chapter", "section" and/or
"subsection" or words of like import for organizational and clarification
purposes only. Such change to the city's ordinances is not meant to amend
passage and effective dates of such original ordinances. (1989 Code)
1-3-2: DEFINITIONS, GENERAL:
Whenever the following words or terms are used in this code, they shall have
such meanings herein ascribed to them, unless the context makes such meaning
repugnant thereto:
AGENT: A person acting on behalf of another.
CITY: The city of Nauvoo, county of Hancock, state of Illinois.
EMPLOYEES: Whenever reference is made in this code to a city employee by title
only, this shall be construed as though followed by the words "of the city of
Nauvoo".
FEE: A sum of money charged by the city for the carrying on of a business,
profession or occupation.
LICENSE: The permission granted for the carrying on of a business, profession
or occupation.
MISDEMEANOR: Any offense for which a sentence to a term of imprisonment in
other than a penitentiary for less than one year may be imposed.
NUISANCE: Anything offensive or obnoxious to the health and welfare of the
inhabitants of the city; or any act or thing repugnant to, or creating a hazard
to, or having a detrimental effect on the property of another person or to the
community.
OCCUPANT: As applied to a building or land, shall include any person who
occupies the whole or any part of such building or land whether alone or with
others.
OFFENSE: Any act forbidden by any provision of this code or the omission of any
act required by the provisions of this code.
OFFICERS: Whenever reference is made in this code to a city officer by title
only, this shall be construed as though followed by the words "of the city of
Nauvoo".
OPERATOR: The person who is in charge of any operation, business or profession.
OWNER: As applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint
owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or lessee of the whole or of a part of
such building or land.
PERSON: Any public or private corporation, firm, partnership, association,
organization, government or any other group acting as a unit, as well as a
natural person.
PERSONAL PROPERTY: Shall include every description of money, goods, chattels,
effects, evidence of right in action and all written instruments by which any
pecuniary obligation, right or title to property is created, acknowledged,
transferred, increased, defeated, discharged or diminished and every right or
interest therein.
RETAILER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, shall be understood to relate
to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things in small quantities
direct to the consumer.
RIGHT OF WAY: The privilege of the immediate use of the roadway or other
property.
STREET: Shall include alleys, lanes, courts, boulevards, public ways, public
squares, public places and sidewalks.
TENANT: As applied to a building or land, shall include any person who occupies
the whole or any part of such buildings or land, whether alone or with others.
WHOLESALER: The terms "wholesaler" and "wholesale dealer" as used in this code,
unless otherwise specifically defined, shall be understood to relate to the
sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things in quantity to persons who
purchase for the purpose of resale.
WRITTEN, IN WRITING: May include printing and any other mode of representing
words and letters, but when the written signature of any person is required by
law to any official or public writing or bond required by law, it shall be in
the proper handwriting of such person, or in case he is unable to write, by his
proper mark. (1989 Code)
1-3-3: CATCHLINES:
The catchlines of the several sections of this code are intended as mere
catchwords to indicate the content of the section and shall not be deemed or
taken to be titles of such sections, nor be deemed to govern, limit, modify or
in any manner affect the scope, meaning or intent of the provisions of any
division or section hereof, nor unless expressly so provided, shall they be so
deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or
reenacted. (1989 Code)
CHAPTER 4
GENERAL PENALTY
SECTION:
1-4-1: Penalty; Fine
1-4-2: Application Of Provisions
1-4-3: Liability Of Officers
1-4-1: PENALTY; FINE:
Any person convicted of a violation of any section or provision of this Code,
where no other penalty is set forth, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed
the maximum fine imposed by 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-2-1 for any one
(1) offense (currently $750.00) and may be required to pay related fees and
costs. (Ord. 2013-9, 3-11-2014)
1-4-2: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
   A.   The penalty provided in this chapter shall be applicable to every
section of this Code the same as though it were a part of each and every
separate section unless otherwise indicated. Any person convicted of a
violation of any section of this Code where a duty is prescribed or obligation
imposed, or where any action which is of a continuing nature is forbidden or is
declared to be unlawful, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. A separate
offense shall be deemed committed upon each day such duty or obligation remains
unperformed or such act continues, unless otherwise specifically provided in
this Code.
   B.   In all cases where the same offense is made punishable or is created by
different clauses or sections of this Code, the Prosecuting Officer may elect
under which to proceed; but not more than one (1) recovery shall be had against
the same person for the same offense; provided, that the revocation of a
license or permit shall not be considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar
any other penalty being enforced.
   C.   Whenever the doing of any act or the omission to do any act constitutes
a breach of any section or provision of this Code and there shall be no fine or
penalty specifically declared for such breach, the provisions of this chapter
shall apply. (1989 Code)
1-4-3: LIABILITY OF OFFICERS:
No provision of this Code designating the duties of any officer or employee
shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any fine
or penalty provided for a failure to perform such duty, unless the intent of
the City Council to impose such fine or penalty on such officer or employee is
specifically and clearly expressed in the section creating the duty. (1989
Code)
CHAPTER 5
MAYOR AND CITY COUNCIL
SECTION:
1-5-1: Composition
1-5-2: Mayor
1-5-3: Meetings Of The Council
1-5-4: Presiding Officer; Vote
1-5-5: Rules Of Order
1-5-6: Mayor, Aldermen Not To Hold Other Public Office
1-5-7: Committees Of The Council
1-5-1: COMPOSITION:
The city council of the city shall consist of a mayor and aldermen, consisting
of two (2) aldermen elected from each ward in the city 1 . (Ord. XI, 9-15-1899)
 
Notes
1 1. See section 1-7-1 of this title for election ward boundaries.
1-5-2: MAYOR:
   A.   Oath, Bond, Term: Before entering upon the duties of his office, the
mayor elect of the city shall take and subscribe and file with the city clerk
the oath of office prescribed by law 1 , and in addition thereto shall execute
a bond with one or more freeholders as security thereon in the penal sum of
three thousand dollars ($3,000.00), the premium for such bond to be paid for by
the city, conditioned that he will pay over all monies coming into his hands by
virtue of his said office, and that he will well and truly and faithfully
perform all the duties of his said office enjoined upon him by the laws of the
state of Illinois and the laws and ordinances of the city, according to the
best of his skill and ability, which bond shall be made payable to the city for
the use of the people of the state of Illinois, and shall be held for the
security of the city and the benefit of all persons who may be injured by the
official acts or misconduct of such mayor. Such bond shall be approved by the
city council and filed with the clerk within ten (10) days after the canvass of
the election returns by the city council and proper notice given him by the
county and in default thereof it shall be the duty of the city council to
declare the said office of mayor vacant and order another election to fill the
said office. The mayor shall hold his office for four (4) years and until his
successor shall be elected and qualified.
   B.   Duties: The mayor, besides being the presiding officer of the city
council, shall be the chief executive officer of the city, and shall also
perform the following duties: (Ord. VI, Art. I, 9-15-1899; amd. 1989 Code)
      1.   He shall, annually, and from time to time, give the council
information relative to the affairs of the city, and shall recommend for their
consideration such measures as he may deem expedient.
      2.   He shall diligently and faithfully inquire into offenses arising
under the ordinances of the city and report the same to the proper officer
whose duty it may be to see that the offender be punished.
      3.   He shall, annually at the regular meeting of the city council in the
month of May, appoint all standing committees and such officers as are or may
be provided for by appointment under any of the ordinances of the city, and
shall, also, at such other times as may be required by ordinance or the
council, appoint special committees to perform certain duties that may be
designated.
      4.   He shall have all the authority and powers conferred on him by
ordinance of the city not repugnant to the laws of the state of Illinois. (Ord.
VI, Art. I, 9-15-1899; amd. 1989 Code; 1991)
 
Notes
1 2. 65 ILCS 5/3-14-3.
1-5-3: MEETINGS OF THE COUNCIL:
   A.   Regular Meetings: The city council shall have at least twelve (12)
regular meetings during each year, to be held in a room provided therefor by
the council, on the second Tuesday of each and every month, at the hour of
seven thirty o'clock (7:30) P.M., except when said second Tuesday shall happen
to be a public holiday, in which case the council shall meet at the designated
hour on the following day; and adjourned meetings may be held for the purpose
of completing the unfinished business of the regular meetings at such time or
times as may be determined by the council. (Ord. XI, 9-15-1899; amd. 1991)
   B.   Special Meetings: The mayor or any three (3) of the aldermen may call
special meetings of the city council, by signing a written call therefor,
notifying the members of said council of the time and place of such meeting,
which notice shall be served by the marshal by reading the same to such members
as are named therein, or leaving a copy thereof at his residence with some
member of his household over ten (10) years old, at least twenty four (24)
hours before the time fixed for such meeting. In case of the absence or
inability of the marshal to serve such notice, the same may be served by a
deputy, any one of the aldermen or the city clerk. In such notice shall be
stated the object and purpose of such meeting; and no business shall be
transacted at any special meeting, except such as the meeting was called for
and notification given thereof, unless by a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of all the
aldermen elected. (Ord. XI, 9-15-1899; amd. 1989 Code)
   C.   Quorum: A majority of the aldermen elected shall constitute a quorum to
do business. Should a quorum fail to attend any meeting, either regular or
special, the members attending may adjourn to a day and hour to be fixed by
them and the marshal shall serve notice on the absent members, of the time and
place of such adjourned meeting. (Ord. XI, 9-15-1899; amd. 1991)
1-5-4: PRESIDING OFFICER; VOTE:
The mayor shall be the presiding officer of the city council, but shall have no
vote, excepting in case of a tie vote, when he shall have the casting or
deciding vote. Should the mayor fail to attend any meeting of the council, the
aldermen present shall decide upon one of their number to serve as mayor pro
tem. (Ord. XI, 9-15-1899)
1-5-5: RULES OF ORDER:
   A.   Order Of Business: A quorum being present and the council called to
order, they shall proceed to business in the following order:
      1.   Calling the roll of members by the clerk. (Ord. XI, 9-15-1899)
      2.   Reading of minutes of the last meeting, and correcting any errors
which may appear therein, or correcting any errors and then approving the
minutes as previously mailed to all members. (Ord. XI, 9-15-1899; amd. 1989
Code)
      3.   Receiving reports of special committees.
      4.   Receiving reports of standing committees.
      5.   Receiving petitions.
      6.   Auditing and acting upon accounts presented to the council.
      7.   The order of the day.
      8.   Any other business which may be brought before the council for
consideration. (Ord. XI, 9-15-1899; amd. 1991)
   B.   Members Arriving After Roll Call: Any member arriving after roll call
may, by consent of the council, have his name entered on the minutes as
present, such entry, however, to show the precise time at which he took his
seat.
   C.   Parliamentary Procedures:
      1.   The city council, in its deliberation and transaction of business
while in session, shall be governed by established parliamentary usage.
      2.   Any member shall have the right to call for the ayes and nays on any
vote which may be taken by the council, provided he does so before the result
of the vote taken is announced by the mayor.
      3.   In all cases of a tie vote, it shall be the duty of the mayor or
other presiding officer, before proceeding to decide the matter by his vote, to
call the ayes and nays, if there should still be a tie, he shall then decide
the matter by his vote.
      4.   No vote of the city council shall be reconsidered or rescinded at
any special meeting thereof, unless at such special meeting there shall be
present as many aldermen as were present when such vote was taken.
   D.   Conduct Of Members: It shall be the duty of all members of the city
council to preserve decorum and conduct themselves in an orderly manner. Should
any member fail so to conduct himself, he shall be called to order, and should
he, after being so called to order, persist in his disorderly conduct, he
shall, on the order of the mayor or other presiding officer, be expelled from
the room during the remainder of such meeting, and may be subject to a fine for
disturbing the peace, under any ordinance of the city providing a penalty for
disturbing the peace within the limits of the city.
   E.   Expulsion Of Members; Procedure: The city council shall have the right
to expel any member thereof, on a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of all the aldermen
elect. It shall, however, be necessary for the purpose of expelling any member
for any offense whatsoever, that specific charges in writing shall be made
against him, which shall be filed with the city clerk, who shall immediately
notify the marshal thereof; that a time shall be fixed by the council for the
hearing of said charges, of which the accused shall have five (5) days' notice
in writing, served by the marshal. Such offender shall have a right to be heard
touching such charges, either by himself or counsel, and if the council shall
find the accused guilty of the offense charged, they may expel him from his
office by a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of the members elect.
   F.   Meetings Open: All meetings of the city council shall be held with open
doors, and all persons conducting themselves in a quiet and orderly manner
shall have a right to attend its meetings.
   G.   Right To Be Heard: Any person having any business with the city council
shall have the right to be heard himself or by counsel or agent. (Ord. XI, 9-
15-1899)
1-5-6: MAYOR, ALDERMEN NOT TO HOLD OTHER PUBLIC OFFICE:
No member of the city council, either as mayor or alderman, shall be eligible
to any other office, either by election or appointment, during his continuance
in office as such mayor or alderman. (Ord. XI, 9-15-1899)
1-5-7: COMMITTEES OF THE COUNCIL:
   A.   Finance Committee:
      1.   At the regular May meeting of the city council of each and every
year, which meeting shall be the commencement of the fiscal year, the mayor
shall appoint three (3) members of the city council to serve as a finance
committee for such year.
      2.   It shall be the duty of said committee to examine the books and
accounts of all the officers of the city, and make full report after receiving
the audit report. In such report shall be set forth an account of all monies
received and from what sources received, and all monies expended and for what
purposes expended by the city as near as may be practicable, during the fiscal
year. (Ord. X, 10-7-1899; amd. 1989 Code; 1991)
      3.   It shall be the duty of said committee to carefully examine and
audit all bills presented against the city, at each meeting of the city council
and report to the council, making in such reports such recommendations as they
may see fit and proper in relation to all such claims as shall have been
submitted to them.
      4.   The reports of said committee shall not be conclusive, but shall be
acted upon by the city council. (Ord. X, 10-7-1899)
   B.   Cemetery Committee:
      1.   At the regular May meeting of the city council of each year, the
mayor shall appoint a committee of two (2) persons, members of the city
council, to serve as a cemetery committee.
      2.   It shall be the duty of the cemetery committee to maintain
supervision over the cemeteries of the city, and to have the same kept in good
condition and neat in appearance as to such committee may seem proper.
      3.   The said committee shall have the power to have all necessary
improvements and repairs made to the grounds, fences or buildings thereon, not
to exceed the sum of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), and shall from time
to time make report to the city council, informing the council of his acts and
doings in relation thereto.
      4.   All claims presented against the city on account of labor performed
or material furnished for any repairs or improvements made on such cemeteries
shall, before the allowance of the same, be approved by the cemetery committee.
(Ord. VIII, 10-7-1899; amd. 1989 Code)
      5.   All graves in the city cemetery shall have grave liners of precast
concrete placed within the grave after it is opened and prior to any human body
being interred in the city cemetery. It shall be the duty of the cemetery
committee to enforce this regulation. (Ord. 1997-7, 1-13-1998)
   C.   Streets, Buildings And Grounds Committee:
      1.   At the regular May meeting of the city council of each year, it
being the commencement of the official year, the mayor shall appoint one
alderman from each ward to constitute a streets, buildings and grounds
committee.
      2.   Said committee shall, from time to time, apprise the council of the
condition of the streets, buildings and grounds in the several wards and inform
the council as to the proper manner to repair or improve the same and make such
plans and offer to the council such suggestions and propositions in relation to
the improvement of the same as in their judgment shall appear to the interest
of the city. (Ord. XXXIII, 10-2-1899; amd. 1989 Code; 1991; Ord. 2008-13, 4-28-
2009)
   D.   Nuisance Committee: The nuisance committee shall consist of three (3)
aldermen whose duties shall consist of apprising the council of the condition
of nuisances within the city. (1991)
CHAPTER 6
OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES
SECTION:
1-6-1: Officers Of The City
1-6-2: Terms Of Office
1-6-3: Qualifications Of Officers
1-6-4: Compensation
1-6-1: OFFICERS OF THE CITY:
   A.   Elected Officials:
      1.   The officers of the city, in addition to a city mayor, city council,
city clerk, and city treasurer, may consist of a city marshal, deputy marshal,
city superintendent of streets and city engineer.
      2.   All said officers, except the city treasurer, city marshal, deputy
marshal, superintendent of streets and engineer, shall be elected by a vote of
the electors of the city, and hold their respective offices until their
successors shall be duly elected and qualified, the aldermen of each ward to be
elected only by the vote of the electors of such ward.
      3.   The mayor may, at the regular May meeting of the city council of
each year, with the concurrence of the city council, appoint a city attorney,
city treasurer, city marshal, city superintendent of streets, city
superintendent of waterworks and city engineer; and in case of vacancy in any
of said offices the same may be filled in like manner at any meeting of the
council. (Ord. V, 9-15-1899; amd. Ord. 240, 5-3-1937; 1989 Code; Ord. 1992-4,
11-10-1992, eff. 5-1-1993)
   B.   Nonelected Officials:
      1.   From and after the effective date hereof, all nonelected officials
of the city shall be hired by a majority of the city council;
      2.   The mayor or mayor pro tem may recommend to the council the mayor's
preference as to the employees to be hired;
      3.   The rejection of the mayor's recommendation by a majority of the
council shall open to the council its recommendations as to the hiring of the
officials of the city. (Ord., 6-7-1972)
1-6-2: TERMS OF OFFICE:
The term of office of the mayor, aldermen, and city clerk shall be four (4)
years; and the term of office of the city attorney, city treasurer, city
marshal, city superintendent of streets, city superintendent of waterworks and
city engineer shall be one year. (Ord. V, 9-15-1899; amd. Ord. 240, 5-3-1937;
1989 Code; 1991; Ord. 1992-4, 11-10-1992, eff. 5-1-1993)
1-6-3: QUALIFICATIONS OF OFFICERS:
   A.   No person shall be eligible to any office who is not a qualified
elector of the city, and who shall not have resided in the city at least one
year next preceding his election. Provided, that no person shall be eligible to
the office of alderman unless he shall be a resident within the ward for which
he is elected, nor shall he be eligible if he is in arrears in the payment of
any tax or other liability due to the city, nor shall he be eligible if he
shall have been convicted of malfeasance, bribery or other corrupt practices or
crimes nor shall he be eligible to any office, the salary of which is payable
out of the city treasury, if at the time of his appointment he shall be a
member of the city council; nor shall any member of the city council at the
same time hold any other office under the city government.
   B.   No person shall be eligible to more than one city office at the same
time, either by election or appointment. (Ord. V, 9-15-1899; amd. 1991)
1-6-4: COMPENSATION:
The officers and employees of the city shall receive such salaries as shall be
determined from time to time by the city council. (1989 Code)
ARTICLE A.  POLICE CHIEF
SECTION:
1-6A-0: Designation
1-6A-1: Appointment; Term; Oath
1-6A-2: General Duties
1-6A-3: Hours On Duty
1-6A-4: City Police Officers
1-6A-5: Part Time Police Officers
1-6A-0: DESIGNATION:
The city marshal is hereby eliminated as a position in the city. All duties
that were performed by the city marshal are devolved to and are to be performed
by the police chief. Any subsequent reference to the city marshal in this code
shall be deemed a reference to the police chief, unless the context deems
otherwise. (Ord. 2005-7, 9-13-2005)
1-6A-1: APPOINTMENT; TERM; OATH:
The police chief shall be appointed at the regular meeting in the month of May
and hold his office for the term of one year and until his successor is
appointed and qualified. Before entering upon the duties of his office, he
shall take the oath of office prescribed by law. (Ord. 240, 5-3-1937; amd. Ord.
316, 7-2-1951; 1989 Code; Ord. 2005-7, 9-13-2005)
1-6A-2: GENERAL DUTIES:
The police chief shall be a conservator of the peace in the city, and shall:
(Ord. VI, Art. II, 9-15-1899; amd. 1989 Code; Ord. 2005-7, 9-13-2005)
   A.   Have authority, and it is hereby made his duty to serve all processes
which may come into his hands, in which the city is a party, and it is further
made his duty to arrest on view and without warrant, all rioters and other
disorderly persons, also all persons engaged in any affrays, routs or unlawful
assemblies; also all persons engaged in any assaults, assaults and batteries or
any other breaches of the peace, or whom he may see violating or attempting to
violate any ordinance of the city; and all persons of suspicious character, and
bring such persons before a court of competent jurisdiction, to be dealt with
according to law.
   B.   Inquire into and report to the mayor or city council all violations of
ordinances of the city, whether the same shall have been committed within his
view or shall otherwise come to his knowledge, and in all such cases he shall
make complaint against such offenders and serve all processes which may be
issued in such cases, when process is necessary. (Ord. VI, Art. II, 9-15-1899;
amd. 1989 Code)
   C.   In the execution of his duty, have full power and authority to call to
his assistance, when necessary, the aid of any citizen or citizens of the city.
If any person required or commanded by the police chief to assist him in the
execution of any duty required of him shall neglect, fail or refuse to assist
such police chief, the person so offending shall forfeit and pay unto the city
the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00).
If any person shall wilfully resist, hinder or obstruct the police chief or
deputy police chief or any of his assistants, or any other officer in the
service of any process under any law or ordinance of the city charged with the
service of such process, or shall resist, hinder or obstruct the said police
chief, his assistants or other officer, in the enforcement of any law or
ordinance of the city, or resist, hinder or obstruct any such officer in the
discharge of any duty whatsoever, arising under any law or ordinance of the
city, or arising under any resolution or order of the city council or command
of the mayor, the person so offending shall be fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this title. (Ord. VI, Art. II, 9-15-1899; amd. 1989 Code; Ord. 2005-7,
9-13-2005)
   D.   Keep a full and correct record, in a book provided for that purpose, of
all arrests made by him, or any other officer of the city as the same may come
to his knowledge, and of all cases prosecuted for violations of the ordinances,
and the manner in which such cases shall finally be disposed of, and he shall
make a written report thereof, monthly, to the city council.
   E.   In subordination to the city mayor, have charge of all measures in
relation to preserving the peace and quiet and protecting persons and property
in the city. (Ord. VI, Art. II, 9-15-1899; amd. 1989 Code)
   F.   In all cases of wilful omission of duty or neglect of any duty imposed
upon the police chief, either by the mayor, the city council, or any law or
ordinance of the city, or law of the state of Illinois, or if he shall be
guilty of malfeasance, misfeasance or nonfeasance in his said office, for each
and every such offense, excepting in cases otherwise provided for by ordinance,
be fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this title, and may be removed from said office at the discretion of
the city council. (Ord. VI, Art. II, 9-15-1899; amd. 1989 Code; Ord. 2005-7, 9-
13-2005)
   G.   Perform all such other duties in enforcing the ordinances of the city
as now are or may hereafter be imposed upon him by the mayor, city council or
ordinances. (Ord. VI, Art. II, 9-15-1899)
1-6A-3: HOURS ON DUTY:
The police chief shall be on duty in the city during such hours as shall be
determined by the city council. (Ord. 316, 7-2-1951; amd. 1989 Code; Ord. 2005-
7, 9-13-2005)
1-6A-4: CITY POLICE OFFICERS:
The city mayor may, with the concurrence of the city council, appoint as many
city police officers as they may think necessary to assist the police chief, on
such occasions as they, in their discretion, may deem proper, to preserve the
peace or protect persons and property. Such city police officers shall take the
same oath as other officers, and shall be held liable for any violations of law
or omission of duty and be held subject to the same penalties as is provided by
ordinance for the police chief. Every city police officer, while on duty as
such officer, shall wear a star similar to those usually worn by peace
officers, as an insignia of his office. (Ord. VI, Art. II, 9-15-1899; amd. Ord.
2005-7, 9-13-2005)
1-6A-5: PART TIME POLICE OFFICERS:
   A.   Employment: The city of Nauvoo may employ part time police officers
from time to time, as it deems necessary.
   B.   Duties: A part time police officer shall have all of the
responsibilities of a full time police officer and such specific duties as
delineated in this code as well as in the guidelines and policies of the city
police department; however, the number of hours that a part time officer may
work within a calendar year is restricted, and he or she shall not be assigned
to supervise or direct full time police officers. Part time officers shall be
trained in accordance with the Illinois police training act 1  and the rules
and requirements of the ILETSB.
   C.   Hiring Standards: Any person employed as a part time police officer
must meet the following standards:
      1.   Be of good moral character, of temperate habits, of sound health,
and physically and mentally able to perform assigned duties.
      2.   Be at least twenty one (21) years of age.
      3.   Pass a medical examination.
      4.   Possess a high school diploma or a GED certificate.
      5.   Possess a valid state of Illinois driver's license.
      6.   Possess no prior felony convictions.
      7.   Have been honorably discharged, if he or she has served in the U.S.
military.
   D.   Discipline: Part time police officers shall be under the disciplinary
jurisdiction of the chief of police. Part time officers serve at the discretion
of the city authorities, shall not have any property rights in said employment,
and may be removed by the city authorities at any time. Part time officers
shall comply with all applicable rules, orders, and guidelines issued by the
city and the police department. (Ord. 2011-11, 3-13-2012)
 
Notes
1 1. 50 ILCS 705/1 et seq.
ARTICLE B.  CITY CLERK
SECTION:
1-6B-1: Election; Oath And Bond
1-6B-2: General Duties
1-6B-3: Neglect Of Duty
1-6B-1: ELECTION; OATH AND BOND:
Within ten (10) days after the canvass of the election returns by which he is
declared elected, the city clerk shall take and subscribe the oath of office
prescribed by law, and shall also, within said time, execute a bond in such
amount as provided by statute 1 , payable to the city, conditioned that he will
well and truly and faithfully perform all the duties of said office of clerk of
the city, according to the ordinances of the city, and pay over all monies that
may come into his hands by virtue of said office according to the ordinances of
the city, which bond shall be approved by the city council and filed with the
city treasurer, to be held by him as security for the city. (Ord. VI, Art. III,
9-15-1899; amd. 1989 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/3-14-3.
1-6B-2: GENERAL DUTIES:
The city clerk shall:
   A.   Keep the corporate seal, attend all city council meetings and keep a
full record of its proceedings and the business of each meeting in a journal
and specifically, the motions, resolutions, and ordinances passed, rejected or
tabled, and make all necessary corrections thereof under the direction of the
city council, which journal, when so corrected, shall be evidence of the facts
stated therein, and shall also transcribe all ordinances passed by the city
council in a book kept specifically for that purpose. Copies of all papers duly
filed in the clerk's office and transcripts of the journals and other records
and files of the clerk's office, certified by the clerk under the corporate
seal, are hereby proven and shall be evidence in all courts in the same manner
as if the originals were produced.
   B.   To accept other responsibilities for which the city clerk is qualified
and which the city council deems are appropriate for the city clerk and such
other duties as the statutes of the state require now or in the future.
   C.   At the expiration of the city clerk's term of office, to deliver to the
successor in office the corporate seal of the city, all books, papers, fixtures
and property pertaining to the city clerk's office. (Ord. 1992-6, 12-8-1992,
eff. 5-1-1993)
   D.   See section
1-6D-3 of this chapter for duties of assistant city collector. (1991)
1-6B-3: NEGLECT OF DUTY:
Should any clerk of the city be guilty of any neglect or omission of duty as
required of him by the ordinances of the city, or be guilty of any misfeasance,
malfeasance or nonfeasance in said office, excepting in cases otherwise
provided for in the ordinances of the city, such officer shall be fined as
provided in section
1-4-1 of this title, and may be removed from said office at the discretion of
the city council. (Ord. VI, Art. III, 6-15-1899; amd. 1989 Code)
ARTICLE C.  CITY TREASURER
SECTION:
1-6C-1: Appointment; Oath And Bond
1-6C-2: General Duties
1-6C-3: Deliver Books To Successor
1-6C-4: Neglect Of Duty
1-6C-1: APPOINTMENT; OATH AND BOND:
The city treasurer shall be appointed by the mayor with the consent of the city
council at the first regular meeting of the fiscal year (regular May meeting)
for a term of one year and until his successor in office shall be appointed and
qualified. The city treasurer shall take the oath of office required by law,
and shall also be required to execute bond with sufficient security in such
amount as provided by statute 1 , payable to the city, for the use of all
persons interested, and conditioned that he will well and truly and faithfully
perform all the duties imposed upon him by the laws of the state of Illinois,
and the ordinances of the city, and that he will pay over all monies which may
come into his hands by virtue of his said office of treasurer of the city, when
payment of the same shall be demanded or required of him, which bond shall be
approved by the city council, and said bond and oath shall be filed with the
clerk of the city and shall be held as security for all persons who shall be
injured by the official misconduct of said treasurer. (Ord. VI, Art. IV, 9-15-
1899; amd. 1989 Code; Ord. 1992-4, 11-10-1992, eff. 5-1-1993)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/3-14-3.
1-6C-2: GENERAL DUTIES:
The city treasurer shall:
   A.   Responsibilities: Maintain an accurate accounting of all funds, fund
balances and reconcile the same monthly; receive all monies from all sources in
the name of the city or accept deposit slips from the collector for deposits
made to the city depository in the name of the city; present to the city
council on a monthly basis a true and accurate report of the finances of the
city; assist the collector in preparing for the annual audit and present all
ledgers, deposit books and notes to the auditors for examination; pursuant to
ordinance 1986-4, making the city treasurer a permanent member of the hotel/
motel tax governing board, shall attend all meetings of the hotel/motel tax
governing board; to learn all aspects of the collector's job; accept other
responsibilities for which the city treasurer is qualified and which the city
council deems are appropriate for the city treasurer. The job description and
general duties of the city treasurer and the salary or other compensation to
the city treasurer may be changed at any time by a majority vote of the city
council and in accordance with the statutes of the state. (Ord. 1992-4, 11-10-
1992, eff. 5-1-1993)
   B.   Books Of Account: Charge himself, in his books of accounts, with all
sums received on account of the city, specifying when, and from whom received,
and shall be allowed to credit himself with all monies disbursed by him under
the order and direction of the city council.
   C.   Books Open To Public, Reports: The books of the treasurer shall be
public documents, open to the inspection of all persons interested therein, and
it is hereby made the duty of the finance committee to inspect the same at any
time it may become necessary, and to compare the same with the treasurer's
account as kept by the city clerk, and it shall be the duty of the treasurer to
make a final report at the regular meeting in the month of May, at which time
his term of office expires, which report shall show the amount of revenue
received, how derived and how disbursed, and shall show the state of finance in
the city, which report, if correct, shall be approved and placed on file, and
shall be published in a newspaper printed and published in the city to be
designated by the city council. (Ord. VI, Art. IV, 9-15-1899; amd. 1991)
1-6C-3: DELIVER BOOKS TO SUCCESSOR:
The treasurer, upon the expiration of his term of office, shall deliver unto
his successor in office all the books, accounts, monies, papers and securities
pertaining to his said office. (Ord. VI, Art. IV, 9-15-1899)
1-6C-4: NEGLECT OF DUTY:
If the treasurer shall omit, neglect or fail to perform any of the duties
required of him by the ordinances and laws of the city, and the laws of the
state of Illinois, he shall be deemed guilty of malfeasance in office, and
shall be fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this title, and may be removed from office. The penalty imposed herein
shall not bar a prosecution against such treasurer and his securities on his
bond nor shall bar any indictment under the criminal laws of the state of
Illinois, for such malfeasance in office. (Ord. VI, Art. IV, 9-15-1899; amd.
1989 Code)
ARTICLE D.  ASSISTANT CITY COLLECTOR
SECTION:
1-6D-1: Appointment
1-6D-2: Bond
1-6D-3: General Duties
1-6D-1: APPOINTMENT:
If necessary, the mayor, by and with the concurrence of the city council, shall
appoint an assistant city collector who shall hold office for a term of one
year and until his successor shall be appointed and qualified. (Ord. 259, 9-7-
1939; amd. 1991)
1-6D-2: BOND:
Before entering upon the duties of his office, the assistant city collector
shall execute a bond to the city in the penal sum of two thousand dollars
($2,000.00), with security thereon which shall be approved by the city council,
conditioned for the faithful performance of the duties of his office, and the
proper accounting for and payment of all monies that shall come into his hands
by virtue of his office, and that he will properly care for and deliver to his
successor in office all of his books, papers and files of his office. (Ord.
259, 9-7-1939; amd. 1991)
1-6D-3: GENERAL DUTIES:
It shall be the duty of the assistant city collector to collect any and all
amounts which may be due the city in relation to any special assessment which
may have been levied by the board of local improvements of the city and
confirmed by the county court of Hancock County, Illinois, and pay the same out
as required by law. It shall also be the duty of the assistant city collector
to make reports to the city council as and when directed. (Ord. 259, 9-7-1939;
amd. 1991)
ARTICLE E.  CITY ATTORNEY
SECTION:
1-6E-1: Appointment
1-6E-2: Oath And Bond
1-6E-3: General Duties
1-6E-4: Reports
1-6E-5: Neglect Of Duty
1-6E-1: APPOINTMENT:
The mayor, by and with the consent of the city council, shall appoint a city
attorney who shall act and hold his office for a term of one year, and until
his successor in office shall be appointed and qualified. (Ord. 254, 6-9-1939)
No person shall be eligible to the office of city attorney unless such person
shall be an attorney at law, regularly admitted to practice law under the laws
of the state of Illinois. (Ord. V, 9-15-1899)
1-6E-2: OATH AND BOND:
Before entering upon the duties of his office, the city attorney shall take the
prescribed oath of office and enter into bond with good and sufficient
security, in such amount as provided by statute 1 , payable to the city for the
use of the city and all persons who may be interested in the conduct of the
city attorney, said bond to be conditioned for the faithful performance of his
duties in said office, and that he will pay over to the city or to any person
entitled thereto, all monies that shall come into his hands by reason of his
holding said office, and which bond shall be approved by the city council and
filed with the city clerk, who shall be the custodian thereof. (Ord. VI, Art.
VI, 1899; amd. 1989 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/3-14-3.
1-6E-3: GENERAL DUTIES:
The city attorney shall attend the meetings of the city council whenever
required to do so by the mayor or city council. He shall be the legal adviser
of the council, and whenever his opinions may be required by the council in any
matter pertaining to the affairs of the city, shall give the same in writing,
if so requested. He shall prosecute all offenses arising under the ordinances
of the city which may come to his knowledge or be reported to him. The said
attorney shall have control of said cases and shall in all matters in such
cases use sound, legal discretion, and may dismiss a case pending if, in his
opinion, it cannot be sustained. He shall also represent the city in all cases
brought against the city, in any and all cases whatsoever pending in any of the
courts, and in all cases commenced by the city in any court whatsoever, and in
the employment of counsel to assist in any such prosecution, he shall be
consulted by the city council in relation to the selection of such counsel.
(Ord. VI, Art. VI, 9-15-1899; amd. 1989 Code)
1-6E-4: REPORTS:
The city attorney shall report monthly to the regular meetings of the city
council the number of cases disposed of, how disposed of, the names of the
defendants, the nature of the charges against them, the number of acquittals
and number of convictions, the number of fines assessed, and what costs, if
any, are taxed against the city in cases where the prosecution has failed.
(Ord. VI, Art. VI, 9-15-1899; amd. 1989 Code)
1-6E-5: NEGLECT OF DUTY:
If any city attorney shall be guilty of malfeasance, misfeasance or nonfeasance
in the discharge of his said duties under this chapter, he shall be fined as
provided in section
1-4-1 of this title, and may be removed from office in the manner provided for
by ordinance of the city. (Ord. VI, Art. VI, 9-15-1899; amd. 1989 Code)
ARTICLE F.  CITY ENGINEER
SECTION:
1-6F-1: Appointment; Oath
1-6F-2: General Duties
1-6F-1: APPOINTMENT; OATH:
The mayor, at the regular May meeting of the city council, shall appoint a
competent person to act in the official capacity of city engineer, who shall
take the oath of office prescribed by law, before entering upon the duties of
his office. (Ord. VII, 10-7-1899)
1-6F-2: GENERAL DUTIES:
The city engineer shall perform such duties as may be properly imposed upon him
by any order of the city council or any ordinance that may exist or hereafter
be passed in relation to any public improvement in the city, or that may be
enjoined upon him by the laws of the state of Illinois, and shall receive
proper compensation for such services as he shall perform for the city, same to
be allowed to him by the city council and paid out of the city treasury. (Ord.
VII, 10-7-1899)
ARTICLE G.  SUPERINTENDENT OF STREETS
SECTION:
1-6G-1: Appointment
1-6G-2: Oath And Bond
1-6G-3: General Duties
1-6G-4: Reports
1-6G-1: APPOINTMENT:
At the regular meeting of the city council in the month of May of each year,
the mayor, by and with the concurrence of the city council, may appoint a city
superintendent of streets, who shall hold his office for the term of one year
and until his successor shall be appointed and qualified. (Ord. VI, Art. VII,
9-15-1899; amd. 1991)
1-6G-2: OATH AND BOND:
Before entering upon the duties of his office, the superintendent of streets
shall take the oath of office prescribed by law, and shall execute a bond to
the city in such sum as provided by statute 1 , with security thereon which
shall be approved by the city council, conditioned for the faithful performance
of the duties of his office, and the proper accounting for and payment of all
monies that shall come into his hands by virtue of his office, and that he will
properly care for and deliver to his successor in office all tools, implements
and other property in his hands belonging to the city. (Ord. VI, Art. VII, 9-
15-1899; amd. 1989 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/3-14-3.
1-6G-3: GENERAL DUTIES:
   A.   It shall be the duty of the superintendent of streets to keep a list of
all implements, tools, materials and other property belonging to the city,
which may come into his possession, and at the end of his term of office to
properly account for and deliver same to his successor. A list of such
inventory shall be kept on file at the office of the city clerk. (Ord. VI, Art.
VII, 9-15-1899; amd. 1989 Code)
   B.   The superintendent of streets shall perform the duty of superintendent
of street labor of the city under the direction of the mayor who shall be
subject to the orders of the city council in relation thereto, in such matters
as the council in its discretion may from time to time see fit and proper.
   C.   It shall be the duty of the superintendent of streets to cause all
ordinances in relation to streets, alleys and sidewalks to be enforced, and to
prosecute in the name of the city all persons violating such ordinances, and he
shall carry into effect all such orders as he may receive from the mayor, city
council or any committee that may be appointed by the council, and for any
wilful neglect so to do, or to perform any duties required of him by the
ordinances of the city, he shall be liable to be removed from his said office.
(Ord. VI, Art. VII, 9-15-1899)
1-6G-4: REPORTS:
The superintendent of streets shall give a report of work done on a monthly
basis to the streets, buildings and grounds committee of the city council.
(1989 Code; amd. Ord. 2008-13, 4-28-2009)
ARTICLE H.  SUPERINTENDENT OF WATERWORKS
SECTION:
1-6H-1: Appointment, Bond
1-6H-2: General Duties
1-6H-1: APPOINTMENT, BOND:
The superintendent of waterworks may be appointed at the regular meeting in the
month of May and hold his office for the term of one year and until his
successor is appointed and qualified. He shall give a bond in such amount as
provided by statute 1 , with two (2) or more sureties to be approved by the
city council. (Ord. 240, 5-3-1937; amd. 1989 Code; 1991)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/3-14-3.
1-6H-2: GENERAL DUTIES:
In addition to those duties set out in title 3, chapter 5 of this code, the
duties of the superintendent of the water department shall include supervising
the monthly reading of water meters, the submission of a monthly report to the
city council covering operation of the water plant, and the making of all minor
repairs to the water meters and waterworks system. (Ord. 315, 7-2-1951; amd.
1989 Code)
ARTICLE I.  CITY COLLECTOR
SECTION:
1-6I-1: Appointment
1-6I-2: Oath And Bond
1-6I-3: General Duties
1-6I-1: APPOINTMENT:
The mayor, with the consent of the city council, shall appoint a city collector
at the first regular meeting of the fiscal year (regular May meeting) for a
term of one year and until his successor in office shall be appointed and
qualified. (Ord. 1992-5, 11-10-1992, eff. 5-1-1993; amd. Ord. 1992-7, 2-9-1993,
eff. 5-1-1993)
1-6I-2: OATH AND BOND:
Before entering upon the duties of his office, the city collector shall take
and subscribe the oath of office and execute a bond in such an amount as
provided by the Illinois Compiled Statutes, payable to the city, under the
condition that he will truthfully and faithfully perform all the duties of said
office of city collector, which bond shall be approved by the city council and
filed with the city clerk to be held by him as security for the city. (Ord.
1992-5, 11-10-1992, eff. 5-1-1993; amd. Ord. 1992-7, 2-9-1993, eff. 5-1-1993)
1-6I-3: GENERAL DUTIES:
It shall be the duty of the city collector to conduct the business of the city
on a day to day basis through utilization of all city ordinances, council
developed policies, and/or direction from the mayor; to issue all permits to
solicit within the city limits based on the ordinance as adopted; to schedule
the use of the city hall, community center and city park when necessary; to
charge and collect, according to the adopted schedule, fees for the use of the
community center; to maintain contact with the city marshal and/or his deputies
concerning the general welfare of the city as information pertaining to local
citizens' needs are transmitted to the city clerk; to assume responsibilities
as chief election official for the city; to maintain and file in records the
hours and wages of the city employees, figure wages, make proper deductions,
and prepare the payroll at the appropriate times; receive and figure meter
readings from water readers and prepare billings and mail billings to the
users; to receive and deposit all monies paid into the city daily and maintain
one deposit slip and forward a second duplicate slip to the treasurer; prepare
listings of all bills presented for payment, coded for appropriation funds, to
the auditing committee for consideration and approval; direct and be
responsible for assignment and duties of the assistant city clerk/assistant
city collector; prepare for distribution the monthly agenda items along with
the minutes of the previous meeting or meetings by the Thursday preceding
monthly city council meeting; to learn all aspects of the city treasurer's job;
to accept all other responsibilities for which the city collector is qualified
and which the city council deems are appropriate for the city collector; and
the job description and general duties of the city collector and the salary or
other compensation to the city collector may be changed at any time by majority
vote of the city council and in accordance with the statutes of the state.
(Ord. 1992-5, 11-10-1992, eff. 5-1-1993; amd. Ord. 1992-7, 2-9-1993, eff. 5-1-
1993)
ARTICLE J.  CITY BUILDING INSPECTOR
SECTION:
1-6J-1: Appointment
1-6J-2: Oath And Bond
1-6J-3: General Duties
1-6J-4: Compensation
1-6J-1: APPOINTMENT:
The mayor, with the consent of the city council, shall appoint a building
inspector at the first regular meeting of the fiscal year (regular May meeting)
for a term of one year and until a successor in office shall be appointed and
qualified. (Ord. 1998-8, 5-11-1999)
1-6J-2: OATH AND BOND:
Before entering upon the duties of his office, the building inspector shall
take and subscribe an oath of office and execute a bond in such amount as
provided by the Illinois Compiled Statutes, payable to the city, under the
condition that he will truthfully and faithfully perform all of the duties of
said office of building inspector, which bond shall be approved by the city
council and filed with the city clerk to be held by him as security for the
city. (Ord. 1998-8, 5-11-1999)
1-6J-3: GENERAL DUTIES:
It shall be the duty of the building inspector to review all applications for
building permit and demolition permit, review the project site or sites,
denoting property lines, estimated construction or demolition costs, labor to
be performed and materials to be used, inform adjacent property owners of the
project site if the proposed construction or demolition is in question of
property lines, to approve or disapprove the application for building permit or
application for demolition permit and to make detailed comments concerning his
reasons for approval or disapproval of an application for building permit or
application for demolition permit. If a building permit or demolition permit is
approved, to conduct inspections during construction or demolition for
compliance with the building permit or demolition permit and make such reports
as he deems necessary to the mayor and city council, and to make permanent and
current records concerning applications for building permit or demolition
permit, their approval or disapproval, and inspections during the construction
or demolition and any other duties which may be assigned to him by the mayor or
city council. (Ord. 2000-11, 4-10-2001)
1-6J-4: COMPENSATION:
The building inspector shall be compensated as set forth in the application for
building permit and as set forth in the application for demolition permit,
respectively, as may be amended from time to time by the city council of the
city of Nauvoo, Illinois. (Ord. 2001-9, 10-9-2001)

1-7-1: ELECTION WARDS; MAP:
   A.   First Ward: The boundary line for the first ward of the city shall be
established as follows:
Beginning at a point at the North Boundary of the City of Nauvoo where Page
Street intersects said North Boundary, then South on the centerline of Page
Street to the North line of Section 12, Township 6 North, Range 9 West, thence
East to the corporate limits of the City of Nauvoo.
All that tract or territory lying West of the centerline of Page Street,
including the extension thereof, to the North line of Section 12, Township 6
North, Range 9 West of the fourth principal meridian, thence East to the
corporate limits of the City of Nauvoo, being East of Page Street and South of
the section line, shall henceforth be included within the corporate limits of
the City and shall constitute the "First Ward" of the City.
   B.   Second Ward: The boundary line for the second ward of the city shall be
established as follows:
Beginning at a point on the North Boundary of the City of Nauvoo where Page
Street intersects said North Boundary, thence South on the centerline of Page
Street to the North line of Section 12, Township 6 North, Range 9 West of the
fourth principal meridian, thence East to the centerline of Warsaw Street,
thence North to the centerline of Young Street, thence East to the corporate
limits of the City of Nauvoo.
All that tract or territory lying East of the centerline of Page Street,
including the extension thereof, to the centerline of Warsaw Street and North
of the centerline of Young Street shall henceforth be included within the
corporate limits of the City and shall constitute the "Second Ward" of the
City.
   C.   Third Ward: The boundary line for the third ward of the city shall be
established as follows:
Beginning at the center of the corner of Young Street and Warsaw Street, thence
South on the centerline of Warsaw Street to the North line of Section 12,
Township 6 North, Range 9 West of the fourth principal meridian, thence East
along the section line to the corporate limits of the City of Nauvoo and thence
North to Young Street, and thence West on the centerline of Young Street to the
place of beginning.
All that tract or territory lying to the East of the centerline of Warsaw
Street and to the North of the North line of Section 12, Township 6 North,
Range 9 West of the fourth principal meridian and lying South of the centerline
of Young Street shall henceforth be included within the corporate limits of the
City and shall constitute the "Third Ward" of the City.
   D.   Map: The following is a map of the city of Nauvoo showing the wards as
set out in subsections A through C of this section:
