Every person to whom any license may be issued shall forthwith place and keep
the same conspicuously posted in his office or place of business and any person
failing or neglecting to so place and keep his license may have his license
revoked by the city council. (Ord. 2002-6, 9-10-2002)
4-1-11: DEATH OF LICENSEE:
In case of the death of any person licensed under this chapter before the time
limited in his license shall have expired, his copartner (if he has any) or his
legal representative may continue to act under such license for the unexpired
term thereof subject to the conditions imposed upon the person to whom the
license was originally issued. (Ord. 2002-6, 9-10-2002)
4-1-12: EXPIRATION OF LICENSE:
It shall be the duty of the city clerk by notice in writing to notify all
persons whose licenses have expired or who are required to procure a license
for their business, occupation or pursuit and are acting without a license.
Such notice shall be given by the clerk immediately upon the expiration of any
license or as soon as the fact that any person is acting without license shall
come to the clerk's knowledge. The notice shall be served by the city marshal
and may be left at the residence or place of business of the person notified.
(Ord. 2002-6, 9-10-2002)
4-1-13: DELIVERY OF LICENSE:
No license shall be delivered to any person applying therefor until all fees
due from him are paid and no person shall be considered as licensed until such
payment and the act of delivery of the license. (Ord. 2002-6, 9-10-2002)
CHAPTER 2
MUNICIPAL OCCUPATION AND USE TAXES
SECTION:
4-2-1: Retailers' Occupation Tax
4-2-2: Service Occupation Tax
4-2-3: Use Tax
4-2-4: Foreign Fire Insurance Companies Tax
4-2-5: Hotel-Motel Tax
4-2-1: RETAILERS' OCCUPATION TAX:
   A.   A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of
selling tangible personal property at retail in the city at the rate of one
percent (1%) of the gross receipts from such sales made in the course of such
business while this section is in effect, in accordance with the provisions of
paragraph 8-11-1 of the Illinois municipal code.
   B.   Every such person engaged in such business in the city shall file on or
before the last day of each calendar month, the report to the state department
of revenue required by section three of "an act in relation to a tax upon
persons engaged in the business of selling tangible personal property to
purchasers for use or consumption", approved June 28, 1933, as amended 1 .
   C.   At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the state
department of revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed on account of the
receipts from sales of tangible personal property during the preceding month.
(Ord. 1969-6, 8-4-1969, eff. 10-1-1969)
 
Notes
1 1. 35 ILCS 120/1 et seq.
4-2-2: SERVICE OCCUPATION TAX:
   A.   A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the city in the
business of making sales of service at the rate of three- quarters of one
percent (0.75%) of the gross receipts received from such business, in
accordance with the provisions of paragraph 8-11-5 of the Illinois municipal
code.
   B.   Every serviceman required to account for municipal service occupation
tax for the benefit of the city shall file, on or before the last day of each
calendar month, the report to the state department of revenue required by
section nine of the service occupation tax act 1 .
   C.   At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the state
department of revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed. (Ord. 1967-7, 8-1967,
eff. 9-1-1967)
 
Notes
1 2. 35 ILCS 115/1 et seq.
4-2-3: USE TAX:
   A.   A tax is hereby imposed in accordance with provisions of paragraph 8-
11-6 of the Illinois municipal code upon the privilege of using in the city any
item of personal property which is purchased outside Illinois at retail from a
retailer, and which is titled or registered with an agent of Illinois
government. The tax shall be at the rate of one percent (1%) of the selling
price of such tangible property, with selling price to have the meaning as
defined in the use tax act, approved July 14, 1955 1 .
   B.   Such tax shall be collected by the Illinois department of revenue for
all municipalities imposing the tax and shall be paid before the title or
certificate of registration for the personal property is issued. (Ord. 1975-2,
4-7-1975)
 
Notes
1 1. 35 ILCS 105/1 et seq.
4-2-4: FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE COMPANIES TAX:
   A.   All corporations, companies and associations not incorporated under the
laws of this state and which are engaged in the city in effecting or soliciting
fire insurance shall pay to the city treasurer, upon July 15 of each year, a
sum equal to two percent (2%) of the gross receipts of premiums received by
said corporation, company or association or their agencies or agents for
business effected or transacted for fire insurance within the city, for the
year ending July 1 preceding said dates. The sum above named shall be a tax or
license fee upon all such corporations, companies or associations transacting
such business within the city.
   B.   Every person acting as agent or otherwise for or upon behalf of such
corporation, company or association shall, on or before July 15 of each and
every year, render to the city clerk a full, true and just account verified by
oath, of all the premiums which during the year ending on July 1 of each year,
shall have been received by him or any other person for him in behalf of said
corporation, company or association, and shall fully and specifically set out
in said report the amount or amounts received as premiums for fire insurance.
   C.   The said agent or agents shall also at the time of the making of the
above mentioned report pay to the city treasurer two percent (2%) upon the
gross receipts of such corporations, companies or associations, obtained in
premiums for effecting fire insurance in the city as specified aforesaid.
   D.   If such account be not rendered on or before the day herein designated
for that purpose, or if the above mentioned rates for the said tax or license
fee shall remain unpaid after that day, it shall be unlawful for any such
corporation, company or association to transact any business of fire insurance
in the city until the requirements hereof have been fully complied with;
nevertheless, this provision shall in no way affect the validity of any risk
that may be taken in violation thereof, between such corporation, company or
association, and the person so insured.
   E.   If any such corporation, company or association shall fail to render
the account or report herein designated by the day required by ordinance, or if
the above mentioned rates, as a tax or license fee, shall remain unpaid after
the day designated, being July 15, every such corporation, company or
association shall forfeit and pay to the city the sum of two hundred dollars
($200.00), upon conviction, for each and every offense, and in addition to such
penalty, the city shall recover in an action in its name for its use against
such corporation, company or association so failing to make such report, or pay
such license fee or tax, the full amount of said license fee or tax, which
would be due under the provisions hereof.
   F.   Any and all sums so received under the provisions hereof shall be paid
to the city treasurer for the fire department of the city, and shall be kept by
the latter as a fund separate and apart from other funds in his hands, and
shall be used for the maintenance, use and benefit of the fire department of
the city. (Ord. 143, 2-4-1918)
4-2-5: HOTEL-MOTEL TAX:
   A.   Purpose: Under this section, the city may exercise its home rule powers
to impose and collect taxes upon the use and privilege of renting, leasing, or
letting a hotel room within the city. (Ord. 2009-3, 9-8-2009)
   B.   Definitions: When used in this section, the following words and terms
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection:
HOTEL OR MOTEL: Any building or buildings in which the public may, for a
consideration, obtain living quarters, sleeping or housekeeping accommodations.
The terms include inns, motels, tourist homes or courts, lodging houses,
rooming houses and apartment houses.
OCCUPANCY: The use or possession, or the rights to the use or possession, of
any room or rooms in a hotel or motel for any purpose, or the right to the use
or possession of the furnishings or to the services and accommodations
accompanying the use and possession of the room or rooms, including rooms that
are properly known as "bed and breakfast" rooms for occupancy purposes.
OPERATOR: Any person operating a hotel or motel.
PERMANENT RESIDENT: Any person who occupied or has the right to occupy any room
or rooms in a hotel or motel for at least thirty (30) consecutive days.
PERSON: Any natural individual, firm, partnership, association, joint stock
company, joint venture, public or private corporation, or a receiver, executor,
trustee, conservator or other representative appointed by order of any court.
RENT OR RENTAL: Any person who occupied or has the right to occupy any room or
rooms in a hotel or motel for at least thirty (30) consecutive days.
ROOM OR ROOMS: Any living quarters, sleeping or housekeeping accommodations.
   C.   Application Of Provisions: This section shall apply to any hotel or
motel operated within the boundaries of the City. (Ord. 1985-3, 4-7-1986)
   D.   Tax Imposed; Rate And Allocation:
      1.   Tax Rate:
         a.   General Tax: A General Tax of six percent (6%) of the gross
rental receipts is hereby levied and imposed upon the use and privilege of
renting, leasing, or letting of a room in a hotel or motel within the City;
however, excluded from said gross rental receipts are the proceeds of any such
renting, leasing, or letting to permanent residents of said hotel or motel, as
previously defined in this section.
         b.   Infrastructure Improvement Tax: In addition to the General Tax
imposed in subsection D1a of this section (and subject to the same exclusion),
an Infrastructure Tax of one percent (1%) of the gross rental receipts shall be
levied. Before March 15, 2012, and before March 15 of each subsequent year, the
City Council and the Hotel-Motel Board shall review the Hotel-Motel Taxes, and
the Council shall thereafter decide whether a change in the Infrastructure
Improvement Tax rate is necessary. Any new rate shall become effective on May 1
of that year. The rate may be changed by no more than one percent (1%) each
year, with the total Infrastructure Tax not to exceed three percent (3%) of the
gross rental receipts. (Ord. 2010-9, 2-8-2011)
         c.   Allocation: The amount of the General Tax shall be allocated
fifty percent (50%) to the Hotel-Motel Tax Board, up to and including seventy
thousand dollars ($70,000.00) per year; any amount over one hundred forty
thousand dollars ($140,000.00) collected from the General Tax shall be
allocated to the City. If the City collects more than one hundred forty
thousand dollars ($140,000.00) from the General Tax in a given year, the City
Council, at the end of that year, may allocate additional money to the Hotel-
Motel Tax Board. Those persons who are subject to General Taxes and Improvement
Taxes may reimburse themselves for that tax liability by separately stating the
taxes as additional charges to the gross rental charged. (Ord. 2018-4, 7-10-
2018)
   E.   Books And Records:
      1.   Every person engaged in the business of renting, leasing, or letting
rooms in a hotel or motel within the City shall keep a separate book or record
of his business as an operator, such that said separate book or record shall
reflect the rents and occupancies taxable under this section as to each
transaction, including those transactions for which no tax is imposed. Failure
by an operator to keep a record of the nontaxable rental receipts shall have
his tax liability computed as if the entire proceeds are taxable hereunder.
      2.   The City Treasurer, or any other person designated as a
representative of the City, may enter the premises of any hotel or motel to
inspect and examine its books and records in order to effectuate the proper
administration of this chapter and to assure the enforcement of the collection
of the imposed tax. No person shall prevent, hinder, or interfere with the City
Treasurer or other representative in the discharge of his duties under this
chapter. (Ord. 2009-3, 9-8-2009)
   F.   Tax Returns:
      1.   Returns Filed: Each person engaged in the business of renting,
leasing or letting rooms in a hotel or motel in the City shall file a return
with the City Treasurer stating:
         a.   The name of the operator;
         b.   The operator's residence address and address of the principal
place of business (if that is a different address) from which he engages in the
business of renting, leasing or letting rooms in a hotel or motel in the City;
         c.   Total amount of rental receipts received by him during the
preceding calendar month from renting, leasing or letting rooms during such
preceding calendar month;
         d.   Total amount of receipts received by him during the preceding
month from renting, leasing or letting rooms to permanent residents during such
preceding calendar month;
         e.   Total amount of other exclusions from gross rental receipts
allowed by this section;
         f.   Gross rental receipts which were received by him during the
preceding calendar month and upon the basis of which the tax is imposed;
         g.   The amount of tax due;
         h.   Such other reasonable information as the City may require.
      2.   Final Return: In the event that any operator or operators cease to
engage in the kind of business which would make them responsible for the filing
of a return under this section, such operator shall file a "final return" under
this section not more than one month after the discontinuance of such business.
      3.   Separate Returns: In the event that a person has or owns more than
one business covered by this section, then in that event such person shall file
a separate return for each business, and shall not file a single return
covering all of said businesses located within the City.
      4.   Execution Of Return: In the event the operator is an individual
entity, then in that event the return referred to above shall be executed by
the owner or one of the owners of said entity. In the event that the operator
is a corporation, then in that event the return shall be filed on behalf of the
said corporation and signed by the president, vice president, secretary or
treasurer, or by a properly accredited agent of said corporation. In the event
that the entity is a partnership, said return shall be executed by one of the
full partners of said partnership. (Ord. 1985-3, 4-7-1986)
   G.   Payment Of Tax; Delinquencies:
      1.   The operator shall pay his tax liability to the City within thirty
(30) days after the end of each calendar month.
The tax referred to hereinabove shall be paid to the Nauvoo City Treasurer at
the time of the filing of each return on a monthly basis, and the full amount
of tax imposed shall be paid. Said payment of tax, in no event, shall be after
the thirtieth day of the month following the month of taxation. (Ord. 1995-4,
7-11-1995)
      2.   Failure of an operator to file a return within thirty (30) days
after the termination of the month of taxation shall result in a penalty
assessed by the City and against said operator in the amount of ten dollars
($10.00). Failure of the operator to pay the tax assessed within thirty (30)
days after termination of the taxing month shall result in a penalty of an
additional five percent (5%) of the amount due. It is understood by this
section that the penalties referred to in this subsection shall be cumulative,
and said penalties shall occur in addition to such other penalties as this
section and Illinois law allow. (Ord. 1985-3, 4-7-1986; amd. Ord. 2009-3, 9-8-
2009)
   H.   Lease Bartering: In the event an operator or operators shall receive
barter in lieu of money in connection with the renting, leasing or letting of
rooms in the normal course of his business, he shall include the value of said
barter and pay the tax subject hereunder, as if the bartering for said room did
not occur. (Ord. 1985-3, 4-7-1986)
   I.   Penalty:
      1.   Any person who fails to comply with any provision of this section
may be punished in accordance with the authority granted to the City under
article VII, section 6 of the Illinois Constitution.
      2.   Any person who is found guilty and convicted of wilfully failing to
pay, collect, report, and transmit the required Hotel- Motel Tax to the City in
accordance with the terms of this chapter shall be punished by a fine of not
less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than three hundred dollars
($300.00) for the first offense, and not less than three hundred dollars
($300.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for the second and each
subsequent offense in any one (1) 180-day period; provided, however, that all
actions that seek the imposition of fines only shall be filed as quasi-criminal
actions subject to the provisions of the Illinois Code of Civil Procedure 1 . A
separate and distinct offense shall be regarded as committed each day upon
which said person shall continue such violation, or permit such violation to
exist, after notification of the violation. (Ord. 2009-3, 9-8-2009)
 
Notes
1 1. 735 ILCS 5/1 et seq.
CHAPTER 3
ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR CONTROL
SECTION:
4-3-1: Compliance Required
4-3-2: Definition
4-3-3: Local Liquor Control Commissioner
4-3-4: License Required
4-3-5: License Classifications; Fees
4-3-6: License Application Or Renewal
4-3-7: License Issuance, Restrictions
4-3-8: Conditions Of License
4-3-9: Revocation Of License
4-3-10: Penalty
4-3-1: COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
No person shall sell or offer for sale at retail any alcoholic liquor within
the city except and under the conditions in this chapter provided. (Ord. 228,
3-5-1934)
4-3-2: DEFINITION:
The term "alcoholic liquor" as used in this chapter shall be held to mean any
spirits, wine, beer, alcohol or other liquor containing more than one-half of
one percent (0.5%) alcohol by volume, which is fit for beverage purposes. (Ord.
228, 3-5-1934)
4-3-3: LOCAL LIQUOR CONTROL COMMISSIONER:
As provided by an act of the state of Illinois entitled "an act relating to
alcoholic liquor", approved January 31, 1934 1 , the mayor is and shall be the
liquor control commissioner in and for the city, and as provided by said act,
such commissioner may appoint a person or persons to assist him as such
commissioner. (Ord. 228, 3-5-1934)
 
Notes
1 1. 235 ILCS.
4-3-4: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale at retail within the corporate
limits of the city any alcoholic liquor without having a retail dealer's
license therefor. (Ord. 228, 3-5-1934)
4-3-5: LICENSE CLASSIFICATIONS; FEES:
Class A license shall authorize the retail sale on the premises specified in
the license, of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises, as well as
other retail sales of such liquor. The annual fee shall be eight hundred
dollars ($800.00).
Class B license shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquors for
consumption on the premises where sold in a restaurant or hotel and then only
when served with meals. The annual fee for such license shall be eight hundred
dollars ($800.00).
Class C license shall authorize the retail sales of beer and Nauvoo wine, by
bottle, can or package not to be consumed on the premises. The annual fee for
such license shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 1974-8, 11-4-1974)
Class D license shall authorize a winery manufacturer's retail liquor license
which gives the right to retail sales of wine, by bottle, can or package, not
to be consumed on the premises. The annual fee for such license shall be two
hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). Winery manufacturer may obtain a special event
license for serving wine by the glass on the premises for a fee of twenty five
dollars ($25.00) per special event. The special event shall not be more than
three (3) days in length and must be at least four (4) days apart. (Ord. 1993-
4, 11-9-1993)
Class E license shall be a special use permit license and shall authorize the
license retailer to sell or serve alcoholic beverages for consumption at
special events off the site of the license retailer as part of a festival,
fair, picnic, or other special or theme event. This license shall allow a
license retailer to transfer a portion of its alcoholic liquor inventory from
its retailed licensed premises to the premises specified in the special use
permit license and to sell or offer for sale at retail only in the premises
specified in the license hereby created, the transferred alcoholic liquor for
use or consumption but not for resale. The licensed retailer shall provide
dramshop liability insurance in the maximum limits and have local authority
approval. The special use permit license may be granted for a duration of one
to fifteen (15) days with a maximum of fifteen (15) days per location in any
twelve (12) month period. The fee for such license shall be twenty five dollars
($25.00).
Class F license shall be a special event retailer's license (not for profit)
and shall permit the licensee to purchase alcoholic liquors from an Illinois
licensed distributor and shall allow the licensee to sell and offer for sale,
at retail, alcoholic liquors for use or consumption but not for resale in any
form and only at the location and on the specific dates designated for the
special event in the license. This license will apply to fraternal,
educational, political, civic, religious and not for profit organizations that
maintain the responsibility for serving and selling alcoholic beverages at
special events. The licensee shall provide dramshop liability insurance in the
maximum limits and have local authority approval. The license may not exceed
fifteen (15) days in any twelve (12) month period. The fee for such license
shall be five dollars ($5.00). (Ord. 1996-2, 6-11-1996)
All the fees so paid to the city clerk as such local licenses fee collector
shall be immediately turned over by him to the city treasurer. (Ord. 1977-3, 4-
4-1977; amd. 1989 Code)
4-3-6: LICENSE APPLICATION OR RENEWAL:
An applicant for a license or renewal thereof from the city of Nauvoo shall be
made to the mayor as the liquor control commissioner in and for the city and
shall be in writing, signed by the applicant or the duly authorized agent,
under oath, and shall contain the following information and statements:
   A.   The name, age and address of the applicant in the case of an
individual; in the case of a copartnership, the person entitled to share in the
profits thereof; and in the case of a corporation for profit, or club, the date
of incorporation, the objects for which it was organized, the names and
addresses of the officers and directors, and if a majority in interest of the
stock of such corporation is owned by one person or his nominee, the name and
address of such person and his nominee and the name and address of the
registered agent for the corporation for the state of Illinois and a
certificate of good standing from the Illinois secretary of state's office;
   B.   The citizenship of the applicant, his place of birth and if a
naturalized citizen, the time and place of his naturalization;
   C.   The amount of goods, wares and merchandise on hand at the time
application is made;
   D.   The location and description of the premises or place of business which
is to be operated under such license;
   E.   A statement that the applicant in the case of an individual; in the
case of copartnership, the person entitled to share in the profit thereof; or
in the case of a corporation for profit, or a club, the officers and directors
and majority shareholders have never been convicted of a felony and are not
disqualified to receive a license by reason of any manner or thing contained in
this code;
   F.   Whether a previous license by any state or subdivision thereof, or by
the federal government has been revoked, and the reasons therefor;
   G.   The applicant will not violate any of the laws of the state of Illinois
or the United States or any provision of this chapter or provisions of this
code;
   H.   Whether the application is for an original or renewal license.
If the application is made on behalf of a partnership, firm or association,
club or corporation, then the application shall be signed under oath by at
least two (2) members of such partnership, firm or association or club or the
present secretary of such corporation. (Ord. 1994-3, 8-9-1994)
4-3-7: LICENSE ISSUANCE, RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Upon the approval of such applicant, the mayor, as such commissioner,
shall issue a license under his hand and seal, the same to be countersigned by
the city clerk and a proper record thereof kept by both said mayor, as such
commissioner, and by the city clerk. No license shall be issued until the fees
provided therefor have been paid and all licenses shall expire on April 30
next, after the issuance thereof. In case a license is issued after May 1, then
the fee shall be prorated for the part of such year for which the license is
issued. (Ord. 228, 3-5-1934; amd. Ord. 87-1, 5-4-1987; 1991)
   B.   No license shall be issued to a person:
      1.   Who is not a resident of the city.
      2.   Who is not of good moral and character.
      3.   Who has been convicted of a felony.
      4.   Who has been convicted of being a keeper or is keeping a house of
ill fame.
      5.   Who has been convicted of pandering, or other crime or misdemeanor
opposed to decency and morality.
      6.   Who does not own or have a lease for the premises for which his
license is sought, for the full period of time for which the license is issued.
(Ord. 228, 3-5-1934)
   C.   The number of places to sell alcoholic liquor at retail shall be
limited to eight (8) and only eight (8) places shall be licensed to sell
alcoholic liquor at retail in the city. (Ord. 1977-3, 4-4-1977; amd. Ord. 1983-
2, 5-2-1983)
4-3-8: CONDITIONS OF LICENSE:
   A.   Hours Of Sale:
      1.   It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale at retail any
alcoholic liquor within the city between the hours of twelve o'clock (12:00)
midnight and five o'clock (5:00) A.M. of any day other than Sunday, and between
the hours of twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight and ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. on
Sunday for packaged liquor and between the hours of twelve o'clock (12:00)
midnight and eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M. on Sunday for liquor by the drink. The
sale of alcoholic liquor at retail by licensees in the city on Sunday, in
strict pursuance of the conditions and restrictions in this chapter contained,
is hereby expressed. (Ord. 2004-6, 9-14-2004)
      2.   On New Year's Eve, alcoholic liquors may be sold at retail until two
o'clock (2:00) A.M. the following morning.
      3.   There shall be no consumption of alcoholic liquor on any portion of
the licensed premises after thirty (30) minutes from the time of closing as
hereinabove stated. (Ord. 1994-3, 8-9-1994)
   B.   License Displayed: Every license shall be hung in plain view in a
conspicuous place on the licensed premises.
   C.   Sales On Credit: No person shall sell or offer to sell any alcoholic
liquor at retail on credit or on a passbook or in exchange for any goods,
wares, merchandise or for services rendered or services to be rendered.
   D.   Duplicate Licenses: No license shall be issued for the same premises
where a license of either class has been issued and is in force.
   E.   Hindrance Of View: No curtain, screen or other contrivance shall be
permitted in or near windows or doors which hinder or prevent a clear view of
the interior of any licensed premises from the street at all times.
   F.   First, Ground Floor: No license shall be issued for the sale of
alcoholic liquor as herein provided, except in a room or rooms adjacent to a
public street that is on the first or ground floor thereof.
   G.   Minor; Drunkard: It shall be unlawful within the city to sell or
deliver any alcoholic liquor to any minor, drunkard or incompetent person.
   H.   Licensed Premises Only: It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale
by any licensee, licensed under this chapter, any intoxicating liquor except on
the premises described in such license. (Ord. 228, 3-5-1934; amd. 1991)
4-3-9: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
The mayor, as such liquor control commissioner, shall have full power and
authority to revoke any retail liquor dealer's license for any violation of any
provision of this chapter, or for any violation of any state law pertaining to
the sale of alcoholic liquor. A conviction for a second violation under this
chapter shall automatically cancel and revoke the license of such person as
convicted, and he shall not be permitted thereafter to procure a license
hereunder. (Ord. 228, 3-5-1934; amd. 1989 Code)
4-3-10: PENALTY:
Unless otherwise provided, any person violating any provision of this chapter
shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00) for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed
committed on each day during which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 228,
3-5-1934; amd. 1989 Code)
CHAPTER 4
RETAIL ESTABLISHMENTS
SECTION:
4-4-1: Tobacco, Cigars And Cigarettes
4-4-1: TOBACCO, CIGARS AND CIGARETTES:
   A.   License: It shall be unlawful for any person to open or keep open any
house or place within the corporate limits of the city for the sale of tobacco,
cigars and cigarettes without securing a license from the city clerk therefor.
Such license shall be effective at the beginning of the fiscal year. If any
person shall be desirous of taking out a license for the sale of tobacco,
cigars and cigarettes, he shall petition the city clerk for the same. (Ord.
199, 5-2-1927; amd. 1989 Code)
   B.   Fee: The license fee for the sale of tobacco, cigars and cigarettes per
annum, shall be the sum of twelve dollars ($12.00). (Ord. 283, 4-2-1945)
   C.   Revocation Of License: The city council shall have the power to revoke
any license issued by virtue hereof whenever it shall appear to the council
that the licensee has violated this section or any police or health regulations
of the city, or the state of Illinois.
   D.   Police Control: Every such place licensed as aforesaid shall be under
the police control of the city marshal, and all lawful police and health
officers.
   E.   Penalty: Any person who shall open or keep open any house or place
within the corporate limits of the city for the sale of any of the
abovementioned articles without first having procured a license as herein
provided shall forfeit and pay not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than
twenty dollars ($20.00) for each and every day such house or place shall be
kept open. (Ord. 199, 5-2-1927)
CHAPTER 5
AMUSEMENTS
SECTION:
4-5-1: Public Shows And Entertainments
4-5-2: Shooting Galleries
4-5-3: Shooting Matches
4-5-1: PUBLIC SHOWS AND ENTERTAINMENTS:
   A.   License: It shall be unlawful for any person, within the limits of the
city, to exhibit any public show, menagerie or circus, or to have any other
public show or exhibition for profit or gain, unless such person shall first
procure a license therefor as hereinafter provided for. Provided, however, that
no scientific or chemical lecture nor any musical concert, shall be considered
a public exhibition or show within the meaning and provisions of this section,
and provided further, that amateur and theatrical corps organized in the city,
of citizens of the city, shall be exempt from payment for any license
whatsoever.
   B.   Application For License: Any person desiring to procure a license for
any such public show, menagerie or other public entertainment shall make
application therefor to the mayor, in writing, and shall specify the nature or
character of such show, entertainment, menagerie or exhibition, and also the
number of exhibitions wished to be given.
   C.   Fees: Such applicant shall pay unto the mayor the following rates,
according to the character of the show, entertainment or exhibition:
 
For all shows, entertainments or        Not less than $1.00 nor more than
exhibitions, other than a menagerie or  $10.00, such license to cover not more
circus, or combination of menagerie and than 2 exhibitions, even though 2 be
circus                                  given on the same day
For a menagerie                         Not less than $5.00 nor more than
                                        $20.00
For a circus                            Not less than $10.00 nor exceeding
                                        $50.00
                                        Not less than $10.00 nor more than
A combination of menagerie and circus   $50.00, in either case not to cover
                                        more than 2 exhibitions
 
   D.   Issuance: The mayor shall use sound discretion in fixing the amount of
license, and upon the payment of the amount fixed, he shall give such applicant
a receipt therefor and endorse and make his order to the clerk to issue such
license, endorsing on said order the amount paid thereon, whereupon the clerk
shall issue the license to the applicant and file said order so endorsed in his
office. Such license shall be in form and substance as follows:
Whereas                      hath on this day made application to the Mayor of
the City of Nauvoo for leave to exhibit                      in said City and
has paid unto the Mayor the sum fixed by him; and, whereas, the Mayor has
authorized this license to issue. Therefore, in consideration of the premises,
this is to authorize and permit said                      to hold and give such
exhibitions on the      day of           , 19  , not however exceeding twice
under this authority.
In testimony whereof I                     , Clerk of the City of Nauvoo,
Illinois, have hereunto set my hand and affixed the Seal of said City this    
day of           , 19  .
[L.S.]                            City Clerk           
   E.   Penalty: Any person who shall hold or give any exhibition such as is
mentioned or described in this section, without first procuring a license
therefor, shall forfeit and pay unto the city a sum not less than fifty dollars
($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00).
   F.   Offenses:
      1.   No obscene, immoral or indecent exhibition or show shall be allowed
or permitted in the city.
      2.   If any person shall publicly exhibit any show or exhibition of an
immoral, obscene or indecent character, with or without license, such person
shall forfeit and pay unto the city a sum not less than fifty dollars ($50.00)
nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00).
   G.   Mayor Guilty Of Offense: If the mayor shall knowingly order the issuing
of any such license for any obscene, immoral or indecent exhibition or show, he
shall be guilty of an offense and shall forfeit and pay unto the city not less
than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00)
for every such offense. (Ord. XXVII, 10-7-1899; amd. 1989 Code)
4-5-2: SHOOTING GALLERIES:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to open or conduct any place within
the limits of the city, for the purpose of shooting at any target, or other
thing, without first obtaining a license for such purpose as hereinafter
provided for.
   B.   When any person shall desire to open a shooting gallery for the purpose
set forth in the preceding subsection, such person shall make application in
writing to the city council, which shall set forth the name or names of such
applicant, together with the location and a description of the room or place to
be occupied and used for such purpose. (Ord. XXIV, 9-22-1899)
   C.   It shall be the duty of the city council, on such application being
made, to inquire into the qualification of such applicant as to such business,
and as to the location and fitness of the room or place in which such applicant
desires to conduct such business, and if it shall appear that such applicant is
a fit person to conduct such business, and such room or place is so located and
arranged as not likely to disturb the peace or result in the injury of any
person, they may grant a license to such applicant. For such license such
applicant shall pay unto the city treasurer the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00)
per annum, the same to be payable quarterly in advance. (Ord. XXIV, 9-22-1899;
amd. 1989 Code)
   D.   Any person who shall open or conduct any place in the city for the
purpose mentioned in this section, without having procured a license therefor
as provided for by this section, shall forfeit and pay unto the city not less
than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than fifty dollars ($50.00) for each day he
shall be in default. (Ord. XXIV, 9-22-1899)
4-5-3: SHOOTING MATCHES:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or maintain what is
commonly called a shooting match, for the purpose of shooting at glass balls or
other objects or to engage in any game as the throwing of balls at targets or
other objects, or any other device whatsoever for the purpose of profit or
gain, within the limits of the city, without first obtaining a license for such
purpose as hereinafter provided.
   B.   Whenever any person wishes to conduct or maintain a shooting match or
any game as described in the foregoing subsection, such person shall make
application to the mayor, designating the place and time where and when such
shooting match or other game or device is to be conducted or maintained.
   C.   It shall be the duty of the mayor, upon such application being made, to
take into consideration the locality of such place as designated by such person
making such application, and if it shall appear that there is no reason to
reject such application or refuse to grant such license, the mayor may grant
the same; provided, that if it shall appear to the mayor that it would be to
the injury or detriment of any person, or any person shall object to the
issuance of such license, the same shall not be issued. (Ord. XXV, 9-15-1899)
   D.   Any person whose application may be approved by the mayor shall pay to
the city treasurer the sum of twenty dollars ($20.00) per day, whereupon the
city clerk, on the order of the mayor and proper evidence of the payment of
such sum, shall issue such license. (Ord. XXV, 9-15-1899; amd. 1989 Code)
   E.   Any person who shall conduct or maintain a shooting match or other game
or device as described in subsection A of this section, in the city, without
first procuring a license therefor, shall, on conviction, forfeit and pay to
the city not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than twenty five dollars
($25.00) for each offense. (Ord. XXV, 9-15-1899)
CHAPTER 6
SOLICITORS, ITINERANT MERCHANTS AND CANVASSERS
SECTION:
4-6-1: Definition
4-6-2: License Required
4-6-3: Application For License
4-6-4: Registration Fee And Term
4-6-5: Consent Of Occupant
4-6-6: Display Of License And Hours
4-6-7: Location Restrictions
4-6-8: Grant Or Refusal Of License
4-6-9: Acts Prohibited
4-6-10: Revocation Of License
4-6-11: Penalty
4-6-12: Exceptions
4-6-13: Special Event Licenses
4-6-1: DEFINITION:
A "solicitor" or "itinerant merchant" shall be deemed to be any person that is
temporarily engaged in the business of selling, bartering or exchanging, or
offering for sale, barter or exchange any goods, wares or merchandise within
the city of Nauvoo, Illinois, who does not own or rent a store, within the city
of Nauvoo, for a period of six (6) months or longer. A "canvasser" shall be
deemed to be any person that is temporarily engaged in the solicitation of
votes, orders, subscriptions, or the like or conducting a survey or poll. (Ord.
2000-13, 7-10-2001)
4-6-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to act as or to engage in business as an
itinerant merchant, solicitor or canvasser within the city boundaries as it
relates to the sale of goods, wares or merchandise, or the solicitation of
orders, sales, subscriptions or business of any kind, or the seeking of
information or donations without first having registered and obtained a license
at the office of the city clerk as hereinafter provided. For an interim
merchant and solicitor, a separate license shall be required for each location.
(Ord. 2000-13, 7-10-2001)
It shall be unlawful for any person, including residents of Nauvoo, to act as
or to engage in business as an itinerant merchant, solicitor or canvasser
within the city boundaries as it relates to the sale of goods, wares or
merchandise in outdoor temporary facilities without first having registered and
obtained a license at the office of the city clerk as hereinafter provided. A
resident of the city for more than six (6) months shall not have to pay the
registration fee. (Ord. 2001-14, 3-14-2002)
4-6-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Any person desiring to secure a solicitor's or itinerant merchant's, or
canvasser's license shall apply therefor in writing over his signature to the
city clerk on forms to be provided by the city, with such applicant completing
all information required on the application including, but in no way limited
to, the following:
   A.   The name and address of the applicant with complete identification.
   B.   The name and address of the person, firm or corporation by whom
employed and the length of service with employer.
   C.   The names of manufacturers of all products or the organization which is
being represented.
   D.   The length of service or solicitation intended by the applicant.
   E.   The proposed method of operation and the nature or character of service
or solicitation intended by the applicant.
   F.   The nature or character of the goods, wares, merchandise or services to
be offered by the applicant, or in general the nature of the business of the
applicant within the city.
   G.   A photograph in a minimum size of two inches by two inches (2" x 2")
full face as to the person or persons who will be soliciting or selling within
the city limits and such other credentials and evidence of good moral character
as may be reasonably required by the city clerk and mayor.
   H.   Must furnish a current Illinois sales tax permit.
   I.   Must provide proof of insurance including liability insurance of a
minimum of three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) per occurrence. (Ord.
2000-13, 7-10-2001)
4-6-4: REGISTRATION FEE AND TERM:
The registration fee and term must be paid to the city clerk prior to any
solicitation or sale and shall be as follows:
 
Term               Fee
1 year             $350.00
180 days           300.00
30 days            200.00
3 consecutive days 50.00
 
The one year license will begin on January 1 and will end on December 31 of
each calendar year. The one hundred eighty (180) day, the thirty (30) day, and
three (3) consecutive day licenses will run from the date of issuance. (Ord.
2000-13, 7-10-2001)
4-6-5: CONSENT OF OCCUPANT:
Any solicitation, sale or other barter or exchange of goods and services at the
home or residence of a resident of the city shall be deemed to be unlawful
unless such selling or peddling has been done at the express invitation or
consent of the occupant of the premises. (Ord. 2000-13, 7-10-2001)
4-6-6: DISPLAY OF LICENSE AND HOURS:
The original license must be displayed in plain view in a conspicuous place on
the licensed premises at all times; business hours must be between eight
o'clock (8:00) A.M. to ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. (Ord. 2000-13, 7-10-2001)
4-6-7: LOCATION RESTRICTIONS:
All solicitors and itinerant merchants shall set up and conduct business or
sales only in areas designated by the city or upon privately owned property
that is zoned for commercial use; there will be no business conducted or sales
in the city parking lot, city park or on sidewalks; and temporary signage will
be allowed but must comply with the city's zoning ordinance 1  and the signage
requirements therein. (Ord. 2000-13, 7-10-2001)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 10 of this code.
4-6-8: GRANT OR REFUSAL OF LICENSE:
It shall be in the sole discretion of the mayor of the city to grant or reject
any application for license as stated in this chapter, which said grant or
refusal shall not be rejected by the city council except by the vote of a
majority of those members present at the next regular city council meeting
called upon to review the application denial. (Ord. 2000-13, 7-10-2001)
4-6-9: ACTS PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to whom a license has been issued
hereunder, to force his way into a home or place of business for the purpose of
solicitation against the will of the person in charge thereof, or to make a
nuisance of himself to the occupant or occupants thereof; and further, in case
any such person so soliciting shall be requested to leave any premises where he
is soliciting business by the person in charge thereof, he shall leave such
premises promptly. It shall be unlawful for any person soliciting business
under a license, issued hereunder, to resort to any fraud, cheating or
misrepresentation in connection with such solicitation; or to solicit a sale of
anything not specified in his application for a license or to violate any laws
of the federal, state, county, or city governments. (Ord. 2000-13, 7-10-2001)
4-6-10: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
Any license may be revoked by the mayor because of any violation by the
registrant of this chapter or any of the provisions of this code, or any state
or federal law or whenever it has been found by the mayor that the applicant
has failed to accurately provide information requested in the registration
statement, which said revocation shall remain in full force and effect until
such time as a majority of the members present of the city council at the next
regular meeting shall have voted upon said revocation. Any revocation shall be
in addition to any fine imposed hereunder. (Ord. 2000-13, 7-10-2001)
4-6-11: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this chapter, unless otherwise provided,
shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00) for each offense, with a separate offense to be deemed
committed on each day during which a violation occurs or continues to occur.
(Ord. 2000-13, 7-10-2001)
4-6-12: EXCEPTIONS:
The provisions herein shall not apply to officers or employees of the city,
county, state or federal government or any subdivisions thereof when on
official business; to persons selling fresh fruits or vegetables of their own
property; children twelve (12) years and under selling lemonade and Kool Aid on
their legal guardians' real estate; newspaper vendors; garage sales and special
events sponsored by the Nauvoo School District and the Grape Festival.
Nonprofit organizations shall be required to file an application but shall not
have to pay the registration fee. (Ord. 2000-13, 7-10-2001)
4-6-13: SPECIAL EVENT LICENSES:
For special events held within the city, any person engaged in the business as
an itinerant merchant, solicitor or canvasser within the city having a license
as hereinabove set forth or any person that does not have a business within the
city that has been established for at least six (6) months prior to the special
event that sells items using outdoor temporary facilities shall be required to
apply for a special event license if they wish to engage in business during the
special event. The mayor shall determine and declare the special events. There
will be a maximum of ten (10) special event licenses issued per event. If more
than ten (10) applications are received, a lottery will be held among the
completed and current applications then on file. Applications for a special
event license shall be received at least forty five (45) days prior to the
special event. The provisions set forth in sections
 4-6-1 through
4-6-12 of this chapter shall apply, except section
4-6-4 of this chapter, the registration fee and term for a special event
license shall be ten dollars ($10.00) per day for the length of the special
event with a minimum of fifty dollars ($50.00) and they must pay for the entire
special event. The term shall be as designated by the mayor to coincide with
the special event schedule.
All displays and exhibits shall be no larger than ten feet by twenty feet (10'
x 20') for the above fee and shall be at least four feet (4') back from the
edge of the sidewalk or public right of way to the front edge of the display or
exhibit. The above fee is for the ten foot by twenty foot (10' x 20') area. If
more area is needed, each additional linear foot over twenty feet (20') will be
one dollar ($1.00) per linear foot per day. (Ord. 2001-14, 3-14-2002)
CHAPTER 7
DRIVE IN ESTABLISHMENTS
SECTION:
4-7-1: Definition
4-7-2: Restrictions
4-7-3: Sign Posted
4-7-4: Penalty
4-7-1: DEFINITION:
A "drive in restaurant", within the meaning of this chapter, shall be deemed to
be any restaurant where meals, sandwiches, ice cream, or other food is served
directly to or is permitted to be consumed by patrons in automobiles,
motorcycles or other vehicles parked on the premises. (Ord. 1965-2, 6-7-1965)
4-7-2: RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person while on or adjacent to the
premises of a drive in restaurant to race the motor of any car or motor
vehicle, to suddenly stop or start any car or motor vehicle, or to make or
cause to be made, any other loud or unseemly noise. It shall also be unlawful
for any other person parked on the premises of such drive in restaurant to blow
or cause to be blown any automobile horn or motorcycle horn at any time while
so parked.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any patron or other person on the premises of
a drive in restaurant, whether in or out of an automobile, to drink any beer or
other intoxicating liquor unless purchased on the premises. It shall be
unlawful for a group of three (3) or more persons to congregate and linger at
any location on the premises of a drive in restaurant other than in the
restaurant building or in a legally parked motor vehicle or at tables placed
outside such restaurant for the consumption of food purchased from such drive
in restaurant. Persons so congregating and lingering shall be deemed guilty of
loitering. No person shall drive a motor vehicle onto the premises of a drive
in restaurant and then from said premises without parking such motor vehicle,
unless there is no unoccupied parking space available on said premises.
   C.   It shall also be unlawful for any person to leave any unoccupied motor
vehicle on any drive in restaurant parking lot and to leave the premises
thereof except with the knowledge and consent of the operator of such drive in
restaurant. (Ord. 1965-2, 6-7-1965)
4-7-3: SIGN POSTED:
It shall be the duty and obligation of the drive in restaurant operator to post
on the premises in a conspicuous location one or more signs bearing the
following legend:
CRUISING IN OR CONGREGATING AND LINGERING OUTSIDE OF A MOTOR VEHICLE IS
UNLAWFUL. NO UNOCCUPIED VEHICLE MAY BE LEFT ON THESE PREMISES WITHOUT THE
CONSENT OF THE RESTAURANT OPERATOR.
(Ord. 1965-2, 6-7-1965)
4-7-4: PENALTY:
Any person found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this chapter
shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not less than fifty
dollars ($50.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00), at the discretion
of the court. (Ord. 1965-2, 6-7-1965; amd. 1989 Code)
CHAPTER 8
PASSENGER HAULERS
SECTION:
4-8-1: License Requirements
4-8-2: Application And Fee
4-8-3: Character Of Applicant
4-8-4: Investigation
4-8-5: Rate Schedules Displayed
4-8-6: Exceptions
4-8-7: Violation
4-8-8: Inspection
4-8-9: Insurance
4-8-10: Name Of Business On Vehicle
4-8-11: Inspection By Owners Or Operators
4-8-12: Traffic Rules And Unlawful Use
4-8-13: License Not Assignable
4-8-14: Approval And Renewal
4-8-1: LICENSE REQUIREMENTS:
No person, firm or corporation shall conduct, maintain, operate, manage, carry
on or engage in the business of carrying, hauling, or transporting passengers
within the city limits of the city of Nauvoo for hire without first having
secured a license therefor. Applications for such licenses shall be made in
writing to the city collector on a form supplied by the city collector and
approved by the mayor and city council. (Ord. 1992-8, 6-8-1993)
4-8-2: APPLICATION AND FEE:
Before any license shall be granted or issued the applicant shall apply for one
of the types of licenses listed below and comply with the terms outlined
therein:
   A.   Sightseeing/Shuttle Service: A business that provides tours of the city
of Nauvoo in a motorized vehicle with a gross vehicle weight (GVW) of less than
ten thousand (10,000) pounds and a seating capacity of less than sixteen (16)
persons including the driver as determined by the manufacturer. The driver must
show proof of a minimum of a class D operator's license, and shall have no less
than three (3) years' driving experience. The vehicle must display a current
and valid safety test sticker issued by a state certified safety test
inspection station which shall be renewed on a semiannual basis. The motor
vehicle used in this capacity shall display current Illinois registration and
it shall be the responsibility of the owner to provide proof of insurance for
the type of business engaged in. The sightseeing/shuttle service shall pay a
fee of ten dollars ($10.00) per seat per year per vehicle on a nonprorated
basis and is valid from May 1 through April 30, and the license shall be
displayed in the front windshield area of the vehicle. A sightseeing/shuttle
service is not restricted to the currently established bus route for the city
of Nauvoo.
A business holding a valid business license issued by the city of Nauvoo and
provides a shuttle service to guests incidental to their regular business and
at no cost or fee shall be exempt from paying the ten dollar ($10.00) per seat
fee, however, all other requirements shall apply.
   B.   Shuttle Service With Seating Capacity Of Sixteen But Less Than Twenty
Five: A business that picks up and drops off passengers at multiple locations
throughout the city of Nauvoo utilizing a motorized vehicle with gross vehicle
weight (GVW) of at least ten thousand (10,000) pounds but less than twenty six
thousand one (26,001) pounds and a seating capacity of less than twenty five
(25) persons including the driver as determined by the manufacturer. The driver
must have a current and a valid CDL with a passenger hauler endorsement, a
current and valid medical card, and comply with all requirements established
for this classification of license as outlined by the federal motor carrier
safety administration, and the Illinois secretary of state. Each vehicle
providing a shuttle service must display a current and valid safety test
sticker issued by a state certified safety test inspection station which shall
be renewed on a semiannual basis. The shuttle service must pay a fee of ten
dollars ($10.00) per seat per year per vehicle on a nonprorated basis and is
valid from May 1 through April 30, and the license shall be displayed in the
front windshield area of the vehicle. This type of shuttle service is not
restricted to the currently established bus route for the city of Nauvoo.
   C.   Shuttle Service With Seating Capacity Over Twenty Five: A business that
picks up and drops off passengers at multiple locations throughout the city of
Nauvoo utilizing a motorized vehicle with a gross vehicle weight of twenty six
thousand one (26,001) or more and a seating capacity of twenty five (25)
persons or more including the driver as determined by the manufacturer. The
driver must have a current and valid CDL with the appropriate endorsements, a
current and valid medical card, and comply with all requirements established by
the federal motor carrier safety administration and the Illinois secretary of
state. Each vehicle must display a current and valid safety test sticker issued
by a state certified safety test station which shall be renewed on a semiannual
basis. The shuttle service must pay a fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) per seat
per year per vehicle on a nonprorated basis and is valid from May 1 through
April 30, and the license shall be displayed in the front windshield area of
the vehicle. This type of shuttle service is restricted to the currently
established bus route for the city of Nauvoo.
   D.   Completion Of Application Form: The applicant shall fully complete the
application for license in writing on the form provided for that purpose by the
city clerk.
   E.   Contents Of Application: The application shall, at a minimum, state the
name of the applicant, the intended place of business, the number of vehicles
to be operated, the designated routes of travel. If a scheduled shuttle
service, the stopping points and approximate times of arrival and departure.
   F.   Maximum Number Of Vehicles: There shall be a maximum total of eight (8)
vehicles operating within the city which can be divided between no more than
two (2) companies. Each company shall be allowed a maximum of four (4)
vehicles. (Ord. 2008-2, 7-8-2008)
4-8-3: CHARACTER OF APPLICANT:
No such license shall be issued to or held by any person who is not a person of
good character or who has been convicted of a felony nor shall such license be
issued to or held by any corporation if any officer thereof shall be ineligible
for a license under the foregoing conditions. (Ord. 1992-8, 6-8-1993)
4-8-4: INVESTIGATION:
The applicant authorizes the city of Nauvoo and any of its public officials,
employees or agents to make any investigation of the applicant as they deem
proper. (Ord. 1992-8, 6-8-1993)
4-8-5: RATE SCHEDULES DISPLAYED:
Rate schedules shall be visibly displayed at all times within the passenger
interior. (Ord. 1992-8, 6-8-1993)
4-8-6: EXCEPTIONS:
This chapter shall not apply to any vehicle(s) delivering passengers from
outside the city and not otherwise engaged in the business of the city. (Ord.
1992-8, 6-8-1993; amd. Ord. 2008-2, 7-8-2008)
4-8-7: VIOLATION:
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor subject to a fine to be set by the city council and court costs and
in addition, upon conviction, the city council may, at its option, revoke any
or all licenses issued to such person. (Ord. 1992-8, 6-8-1993; amd. Ord. 2008-
2, 7-8-2008)
4-8-8: INSPECTION:
Any person owning, operating or controlling any vehicle hauling passengers for
hire within the city shall not operate any of these vehicles without first
having been inspected and issued a certificate to the effect that the vehicle
(s) passes the semiannual inspection to be performed by the city police
department or other department as designated by the mayor with approval of the
city council. The inspection shall not be limited to, but shall include, the
following areas in particular:
   A.   Foot brakes and hand or parking brakes;
   B.   Front and rear bumpers, or original manufacturer's equipment;
   C.   Spare tire inflation;
   D.   Sufficient heating and ventilation for the passenger interior;
   E.   Driver's rearview mirror;
   F.   Speedometer operation;
   G.   Windshield wiper(s);
   H.   Lights, as approved by the motor vehicle department, and passenger
compartment lights with accessible switch;
   I.   No broken or cracked glass;
   J.   Passenger seat belts;
   K.   Horn;
   L.   Muffler. (Ord. 1992-8, 6-8-1993; amd. Ord. 2008-2, 7-8-2008)
4-8-9: INSURANCE:
Prior to the commencement of operation, the licensee shall have on deposit with
the city clerk an insurance policy, policies or certificate of insurance of a
company licensed to do business in Illinois, together with a certificate from
the insurance company to the effect that said policy will not be canceled or
terminated except after ten (10) days' notice to the city. A copy of this
insurance will be forwarded to the Illinois Municipal League Risk Management
Company. Said insurance shall maintain in effect a minimum of five hundred
thousand dollars ($500,000.00) liability insurance and shall include the city
of Nauvoo as being additionally insured on this policy. (Ord. 1992-8, 6-8-1993;
amd. Ord. 2008-2, 7-8-2008)
4-8-10: NAME OF BUSINESS ON VEHICLE:
The vehicle(s) shall have the name under which the business hauling passengers
for hire is being conducted painted or otherwise imprinted on the vehicle in a
generally conspicuous and readable location in letters at least four inches
(4") in height and in color or colors contrasting with the vehicle. (Ord. 1992-
8, 6-8-1993; amd. Ord. 2008-2, 7-8-2008)
4-8-11: INSPECTION BY OWNERS OR OPERATORS:
Every vehicle owner or operator hauling passengers for hire shall make an
inspection at least once each week of all vehicles being operated and shall
keep all vehicles in proper repair and sanitary condition at all times. Any
vehicle found by the owner or operator to be unsafe or unsanitary shall have
such repairs and alterations made as may be necessary and said owner or
operator shall not operate or permit to be operated any vehicle that is unsafe
or unsanitary in hauling passengers for hire. (Ord. 1992-8, 6-8-1993; amd. Ord.
2008-2, 7-8-2008)
4-8-12: TRAFFIC RULES AND UNLAWFUL USE:
It shall be the duty of every operator to obey the bus route ordinance 1  of
the city of Nauvoo. (Ord. 2001-16, 4-9-2002; amd. Ord. 2008-2, 7-8-2008)
It shall be the duty of every operator to obey all traffic rules established by
law and it shall be unlawful to permit any vehicle to be used in the
perpetration of a crime or misdemeanor.
It shall be unlawful for any operator while on duty to drink any intoxicating
liquor, or to use any profane or obscene language, or to shout or call to
prospective passengers or to disturb the peace in any way. (Ord. 1992-8, 6-8-
1993; amd. Ord. 2008-2, 7-8-2008)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 9, chapter 5 of this code.
4-8-13: LICENSE NOT ASSIGNABLE:
No license may be assigned, sold, loaned, transferred, used as collateral or
otherwise incumbered. No person shall alter, deface, forge or counterfeit any
license issued. (Ord. 1992-8, 6-8-1993; amd. Ord. 2008-2, 7-8-2008)
4-8-14: APPROVAL AND RENEWAL:
If after due consideration of the information contained within the application,
any investigative reports and inspection reports, the mayor determines that the
application is satisfactory, he will approve the application. Thereupon, the
city collector shall notify the applicant that the application has been
approved and the license shall be signed by the mayor, attested to by the city
clerk and issued for a period of one year.
Within thirty (30) days from expiration, an application for renewal may be made
in writing to the city collector on a form supplied by the city collector and
approved by the mayor and city council. After the expiration of a license, any
person, firm or corporation shall make application as set forth hereinabove as
if no previous license had been issued. (Ord. 1992-8, 6-8-1993; amd. Ord. 2008-
2, 7-8-2008)
CHAPTER 9
BED AND BREAKFAST AND GUESTHOUSE ESTABLISHMENTS
SECTION:
4-9-1: Definitions
4-9-2: License Required
4-9-3: Mandatory Inspection Report
4-9-4: Liability Insurance
4-9-5: License And Annual Fees
4-9-6: Form, And Display, Of License
4-9-7: Penalty For Violation
4-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
BED AND BREAKFAST ESTABLISHMENT (B&B): An operator occupied residence providing
accommodations and breakfast for a charge to the public with no more than five
(5) guestrooms for rent.
GUEST HOUSE/SUITE: A private residence or other establishment normally
providing a kitchen, dining area and from one to six (6) bedrooms for a charge
to the public. Neither entity operates as a hotel, motel, or boarding house.
(Ord. 2012-5, 12-11-2012)
4-9-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person or entity shall operate a bed and breakfast establishment or a guest
house/suite without first having obtained a required business license from the
city. A license for such establishments may not be issued until the owner has
obtained a special use permit from the city if required for zoning compliance,
a certificate of inspection, and meets the city's insurance requirements.
For the purpose of this chapter, the city of Nauvoo adopts the bed and
breakfast act of the state of Illinois ("B&B act") 1  and each B&B is required
to be in compliance with the act. To the extent that the provisions of this
chapter conflict with the provisions of the B&B act, the provisions of this
chapter shall prevail. (Ord. 2012-5, 12-11-2012)
 
Notes
1 1. 50 ILCS 820/1 et seq.
4-9-3: MANDATORY INSPECTION REPORT:
No license shall be issued until the following inspection report has been filed
with the city:
   A.   A basic fire and safety inspection report from the fire marshal, fire
chief, or building inspector. The inspection is based on the current fire and
life safety regulations of the state of Illinois applicable to B&Bs and guest
houses/suites, with the provisions of title 7, chapter 2 of this code, and with
the fire and life safety regulations in the most current edition of the NFPA
life safety code. Upon application, the city will consider substituting a
comparable inspection report completed by a "certified" insurance property
inspector from the owner's insurance company. If the application is approved,
the annual licensing fee will be twenty five dollars ($25.00) for each year
their inspection report is accepted.
   B.   B&Bs must meet the food handling certification required by the B&B act.
   C.   A new inspection report will be required every year unless a formal
written complaint from a guest of the establishment requests an inspection
prior to the next required inspection. If more than one inspection is done
during a licensing year, the owner will pay fifty dollars ($50.00) for each
additional inspection or reinspection. If owner fails to make the required
repairs or changes within thirty (30) days of an interim inspection, the
license will be revoked. A license reinstatement fee of fifty dollars ($50.00)
will be charged for the remainder of the fiscal year when in compliance. The
penalty prescribed in this chapter will apply to any establishment operating
without a license. (Ord. 2012-5, 12-11-2012)
4-9-4: LIABILITY INSURANCE:
The operator of a bed and breakfast establishment or a guest house/suite is
required to maintain a general liability insurance policy with limits of at
least five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) covering its establishment
and to provide the city with a certificate of insurance. If there is any change
in insurance status during the license period, the operator of that
establishment shall immediately notify the city, in writing, of the change and
shall provide a copy of the new insurance certificate. The city may amend the
business license to reflect the status change. (Ord. 2012-5, 12-11-2012)
4-9-5: LICENSE AND ANNUAL FEES:
   A.   Each operator of a bed and breakfast establishment or a guest house/
suite who applies for a required license shall pay a license fee of sixty
dollars ($60.00) if the premises contains one or two (2) buildings. If the
premises contains more than two (2) buildings, the applicant must pay ten
dollars ($10.00) for each additional unit, up to a maximum of one hundred
dollars ($100.00). This fee will cover the cost of the annual inspection and
one reinspection, if required. If the establishment does not pass on the first
reinspection, an additional fifty dollars ($50.00) will be charged for each
subsequent reinspection until compliance.
   B.   Before March 1 of each year, each licensee who wishes to renew its
business license for the next fiscal year beginning May 1 shall pay an annual
license fee of sixty dollars ($60.00). After payment of the annual fee, and
before May 1, the licensee shall submit a current certificate of insurance and
meet the inspection requirements. Payments made after May 10 will be assessed a
twenty five dollar ($25.00) late penalty. (Ord. 2012-5, 12-11-2012)
4-9-6: FORM, AND DISPLAY, OF LICENSE:
The license shall be in such form, and shall include such information, as may
be prescribed from time to time by the city. The issued license shall be
conspicuously displayed near the entrance of the premises. (Ord. 2012-5, 12-11-
2012)
4-9-7: PENALTY FOR VIOLATION:
A violation of any provision of this chapter shall be punishable by a fine of
not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day up to a maximum of one
thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00). The city shall notify the
establishment operator of such violation and allow the operator thirty (30)
days to cure such violation. Each day the violation continues past thirty (30)
days of notice shall constitute a separate offense. If the city seeks court
intervention to obtain compliance, the violator also must pay all court costs
and fees associated with the enforcement of the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 2012-5, 12-11-2012)
CHAPTER 10
MUNICIPAL GAS USE TAX
SECTION:
4-10-1: Short Title
4-10-2: Definitions
4-10-3: Tax
4-10-4: Collection Of Tax By Public Utility
4-10-5: Books And Records
4-10-1: SHORT TITLE:
The tax imposed by this chapter shall be known as the "Municipal Gas Use Tax"
and is imposed in addition to all other taxes imposed by the City of Nauvoo,
the State of Illinois, or any other Municipal corporation or political
subdivision of the State. (Ord. 2015-5, 5-10-2016)
4-10-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply:
PERSON: Any individual, firm, trust, estate, partnership, association, joint
stock company, joint venture, corporation, limited liability company, Municipal
corporation or political subdivision of this State, or a receiver, trustee,
conservator or other representative appointed by order of any court.
PUBLIC UTILITIES ACT: The Public Utilities Act 1  as amended.
PUBLIC UTILITY: As defined in section 3-105 of the Public Utilities Act.
RETAIL PURCHASER: Any person who purchases gas in a sale at retail.
SALE AT RETAIL: Any sale of gas by a retailer to a person for use or
consumption, and not for resale. For this purpose, the term "retailer" means
any person engaged in the business of distributing, supplying, furnishing or
selling gas. (Ord. 2015-5, 5-10-2016)
 
Notes
1 1. 220 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq.
4-10-3: TAX:
   A.   Except as otherwise provided by this chapter, a tax is imposed on the
privilege of using or consuming gas in the City that is purchased in a sale at
retail at the rate of: one and one-fourth cents ($0.0125) per therm with
respect to all bills issued on or after July 1, 2016. (Ord. 2017-4, 6-19-2017)
   B.   The ultimate incidence of and liability for payment of the tax is on
the retail purchaser, and nothing in this chapter shall be construed to impose
a tax on the occupation of distributing, supplying, furnishing, selling or
transporting gas.
   C.   The retail purchaser shall pay the tax, measured by therms of gas
delivered to the retail purchaser's premises, to the public utility designated
to collect the tax pursuant to section
4-10-4 of this chapter on or before the payment due date of the public
utility's bill first reflecting the tax, or directly to the City Treasurer on
or before the fifteenth day of the second month following the month in which
the gas is delivered to the retail purchaser if no public utility has been
designated to collect the tax pursuant to section
4-10-4 of this chapter or if the gas is delivered by a person other than a
public utility so designated.
   D.   Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to impose a tax upon any
person, business or activity which, under the Constitutions of the United
States or State of Illinois, may not be made the subject of taxation by the
City.
   E.   A person who purchases gas for resale and therefore does not pay the
tax imposed by this chapter with respect to the use or consumption of the gas,
but who later uses or consumes part or all of the gas, shall pay the tax
directly to the City Treasurer on or before the fifteenth day of the second
month following the month in which the gas is used or consumed.
   F.   The tax shall apply to gas for which the delivery to the retail
purchaser is billed by a public utility on or after July 1, 2016.
   G.   If it shall appear that an amount of tax has been paid which was not
due under the provisions of this chapter, whether as a result of mistake of
fact or an error of law, then such amount shall be: 1) credited against any tax
due, or to become due, under this chapter from the taxpayer who made the
erroneous payment or 2) subject to a refund if no such tax is due or to become
due; provided that no amounts erroneously paid more than three (3) years prior
to the filing of a claim therefor shall be so credited or refunded.
   H.   No action to recover any amount of tax due under the provisions of this
chapter shall be commenced more than three (3) years after the due date of such
amount. (Ord. 2015-5, 5-10-2016)
4-10-4: COLLECTION OF TAX BY PUBLIC UTILITY:
The Mayor and City Treasurer are each authorized to enter into a contract for
collection of the tax imposed by this chapter with any public utility providing
gas service in the City. The contract shall include and substantially conform
with the following provisions:
   A.   The public utility will collect the tax from retail purchasers as an
independent contractor;
   B.   The public utility will remit collected taxes to the City Treasurer no
more often than once each month;
   C.   The public utility will be entitled to withhold from tax collections a
service fee equal to three percent (3%) of the amounts collected and timely
remitted to the City Treasurer;
   D.   The public utility shall not be responsible to the City for any tax not
actually collected from a retail purchaser; and
   E.   Such additional terms as the parties may agree upon. (Ord. 2015-5, 5-
10-2016)
4-10-5: BOOKS AND RECORDS:
Every taxpayer shall keep accurate books and records, including original source
documents and books of entry, denoting the activities or transactions that gave
rise, or may have given rise to any tax liability or exemption under this
chapter. All such books and records shall, at all times during business hours,
be subject to and available for inspection by the City. (Ord. 2015-5, 5-10-
2016)
CHAPTER 11
MUNICIPAL ELECTRICITY TAX
SECTION:
4-11-1: Tax Imposed
4-11-2: Exceptions
4-11-3: Additional Taxes
4-11-4: Collection
4-11-5: Reports To Municipality
4-11-6: Credit For Overpayment
4-11-7: Penalty
4-11-1: TAX IMPOSED:
A tax is imposed on all persons engaged in the following occupations or
exercising the following privileges: The privilege of using or consuming
electricity acquired in a purchase at retail and used or consumed within the
corporate limits of the Municipality, at specified rates, to be calculated on a
monthly basis for each purchaser.
   A.   Pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-11-2, the rates set forth
below shall be effective from July 1, 2016 through June 30, 2017, for
residential and non-residential customers:
      1.   For the first 2,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month:
$0.001525 (0.1525 cents) per kilowatt-hour;
      2.   For the next 48,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month:
$0.001 (0.1 cents) per kilowatt-hour;
      3.   For the next 50,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month:
$0.0009 (0.09 cents) per kilowatt-hour;
      4.   For the next 400,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month:
$0.000875 (0.0875 cents) per kilowatt-hour;
      5.   For the next 500,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month:
$0.00085 (0.085 cents) per kilowatt-hour;
      6.   For the next 2,000,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month:
$0.0008 (0.08 cents) per kilowatt-hour;
      7.   For the next 2,000,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month:
$0.0007875 (0.07875 cents) per kilowatt-hour;
      8.   For the next 5,000,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month:
$0.000775 (0.0775 cents) per kilowatt-hour;
      9.   For the next 10,000,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month:
$0.0007625 (0.07625 cents) per kilowatt-hour; and
      10.   For all electricity used or consumed in excess of 20,000,000
kilowatt-hours in a month: $0.00075 (0.075 cents) per kilowatt- hour. (Ord.
2015-6, 5-10-2016)
   B.   The City Council shall review the tax rates periodically and shall
change them by passage of an ordinance as necessary. (Ord. 2017-5, 6-19-2017)
4-11-2: EXCEPTIONS:
None of the taxes authorized by this chapter may be imposed with respect to any
transaction in interstate commerce or otherwise to the extent to which the
business or privilege may not, under the Constitution and Statutes of the
United States, be made the subject of taxation by this State or any political
subdivision thereof; nor shall any persons engaged in the business of
distributing, supplying, furnishing, or selling or transmitting gas, water, or
electricity, or engaged in the business of transmitting messages, or using or
consuming electricity acquired in a purchase at retail, be subject to taxation
under the provisions of this chapter for those transactions that are or may
become subject to taxation under the provisions of the Municipal Retailers'
Occupation Tax Act as authorized by 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-11-1; nor
shall any tax authorized by this chapter be imposed upon any person engaged in
a business or on any privilege unless the tax is imposed in like manner and at
the same rate upon all persons engaged in businesses of the same class in the
Municipality, whether privately or Municipally owned or operated, or exercising
the same privilege within the Municipality. Any account of the City of Nauvoo
is exempt from the tax imposed in section
4-11-1 of this chapter. (Ord. 2015-6, 5-10-2016)
4-11-3: ADDITIONAL TAXES:
Such tax shall be in addition to other taxes levied upon the taxpayer or its
business. (Ord. 2015-6, 5-10-2016)
4-11-4: COLLECTION:
The tax authorized by this chapter shall be collected from the purchaser by the
person maintaining a place of business in this State who delivers the
electricity to the purchaser. This tax shall constitute a debt of the purchaser
to the person who delivers the electricity to the purchaser and if unpaid, is
recoverable in the same manner as the original charge for delivering the
electricity. Any tax required to be collected pursuant to this chapter and any
such tax collected by a person delivering electricity shall constitute a debt
owed to the Municipality by such person delivering the electricity. Persons
delivering electricity shall collect the tax from the purchaser by adding such
tax to the gross charge for delivering the electricity. Persons delivering
electricity shall also be authorized to add to such gross charge an amount
equal to three percent (3%) of the tax to reimburse the person delivering
electricity for the expense incurred in keeping records, billing customers,
preparing and filing returns, remitting the tax and supplying data to the
Municipality upon request. If the person delivering electricity fails to
collect the tax from the purchaser, then the purchaser shall be required to pay
the tax directly to the Municipality in the manner prescribed by the
Municipality. On or before the last day of each month, persons delivering
electricity shall make a return to the City for the preceding month and shall,
at the time of filing such return, pay the Municipality the amount of the tax
collected pursuant to this chapter. (Ord. 2015-6, 5-10-2016)
