CHAPTER 1
GENERAL TRAFFIC REGULATIONS
SECTION:
9-1-1: Definitions
9-1-2: Driving Vehicles On Public Ways
9-1-3: Driving Through Processions
9-1-4: Vehicles Not To Obstruct Traffic
9-1-5: Age Limits For Drivers
9-1-6: Vehicle Equipment
9-1-7: Obeying Officers And Traffic Control Signs And Signals
9-1-8: Speed Limits
9-1-9: Driving In Careless Or Disorderly Manner
9-1-10: Racing Automobiles
9-1-11: Illinois Vehicle Code Adopted
9-1-12: Penalty
9-1-1: DEFINITIONS:
CONGESTED DISTRICT: That part of the City described as follows: Mulholland
Street from Wells Street east to Wilcox Street, Bluff Street from Mulholland
Street north to Knight Street, and Page Street from White Street north to
Knight Street.
DRIVER: The rider and driver of a horse or horses, the rider of wheels, the
operator of motor vehicles.
HISTORICAL DISTRICT: That part of the City described as follows: Water Street
from Durphy to Bain Streets, Bain Street from Water to White Streets, White
Street from Bain to Durphy Streets, Durphy Street from White to Water Streets.
HORSES: All domestic animals.
VEHICLE: Equestrians, led horses, carts, drays, omnibuses, carriages, buggies,
wagons, motor vehicles, automobiles, motorcycles, and all other vehicles used
for transporting persons or property on the public streets, however drawn,
driven or propelled, except carts, carriages and barrows propelled by hand.
(Ord. 129, 9-5-1916; amd. 1991; Ord. 1993-5, 1-11-1994)
9-1-2: DRIVING VEHICLES ON PUBLIC WAYS:
   A.   Careful Driving: Vehicles shall be driven in a careful manner and with
due regard for the safety and convenience of pedestrians, also of other
vehicles.
   B.   Driving On Right: Vehicles shall keep to the right side of the center
of the street.
   C.   Slow Vehicles: Vehicles moving slowly shall keep as close as possible
to the curb on the right, allowing more swiftly moving vehicles free passage to
the left.
   D.   Turning Movements:
      1.   Vehicles turning to the left into an intersecting street shall pass
and turn the corner as near to the right hand curb as possible.
      2.   Vehicles turning to the left into an intersecting street shall pass
to the right of and beyond the center of the street intersection before
turning.
   E.   Meeting Vehicles: Vehicles meeting shall pass each other to the right.
   F.   Passing: A vehicle overtaking another vehicle traveling in the same
direction shall keep to the left of the overtaken vehicle in passing.
   G.   Backing To Turn: No vehicle shall back to make a turn in any street if
by so doing it interferes with other vehicles, but shall go around the block or
to a street sufficiently wide to turn without backing.
   H.   Crossing Street: Vehicles crossing from one side of the street to the
other shall do so by turning to the left so as to head in the same direction as
the traffic on that side of the street toward which the crossing is made, and
when the street is congested with traffic, such vehicles shall go to the
intersection before turning, and no vehicle shall stop with its left side to
the curb. (Ord. 129, 9-5-1916)
   I.   Backing To Curb: No vehicle shall remain backed up to the curb except
when such vehicle is actually loading or unloading, and in such case no longer
than the actual loading or unloading requires. (Ord. 129, 9-5-1916; amd. 1989
Code)
   J.   Waiting At Curb: A vehicle waiting at the curb shall promptly give
place to a vehicle about to take on or let off passengers.
   K.   Stopping On Street: No vehicle shall stop on any street, except in an
emergency, unless within six inches (6") of the curb, nor in such a way as to
obstruct the free passage of other vehicles.
   L.   Stopping Near Intersections: No vehicle shall stop or stand within any
street intersection nor within ten feet (10') of the line of any intersecting
street in the congested district, nor outside of said district for a longer
period than is necessary to load and unload.
   M.   Signal From Officer: The driver of any vehicle shall stop upon the
signal from a police officer.
   N.   Signals From Drivers: The driver or operator of every motor vehicle
shall give some plainly visible or audible sign to other approaching vehicles
before stopping. Drivers and operators of motor vehicles shall, in approaching
or traversing a crossing or street intersection, have their vehicles under
control, and shall give warning to other vehicles and to pedestrians of their
approach.
   O.   Running Motors: No motor vehicle shall be left standing in any street
with the motor running unless some person competent to manage said vehicle
shall be left in charge thereof.
   P.   Vehicles Being Passed: Every person in charge of a vehicle shall pull
to the right side of the street or road when signaled from a vehicle behind
desiring to pass. (Ord. 129, 9-5-1916)
   Q.   Operation Of A Low-Speed Vehicle; Restricted Streets 1 : A low- speed
vehicle (LSV) legally operating upon a street or roadway under State law also
may operate on streets and roadways under the jurisdiction of the City of
Nauvoo that have a posted speed limit of thirty five (35) mph or less.
      1.   License Requirement: A person may not operate an LSV unless he or
she has a valid driver's license issued by the Secretary of State or by a
foreign jurisdiction.
      2.   Minimum Equipment Requirements: An LSV may not be operated within
the City limits unless the vehicle has the following equipment: a parking
brake; a steering apparatus; tires; a windshield that conforms to the Federal
vehicle safety standards on glazing materials as set forth in 49 CFR part
571.205; a vehicle identification number; seat belts; a rearview mirror; an
exterior rearview mirror mounted on the driver's side of the vehicle; red
reflectorized warning devices on each rear side and one on the center rear of
the vehicle; a headlight that emits a white light visible from a distance of
five hundred feet (500') to the front; a tail lamp that emits a red light
visible from at least one hundred feet (100') from the rear; brake lights; and
front and rear turn signals. It also must have a slow moving vehicle emblem at
the rear of the vehicle.
      3.   Miscellaneous Requirements:
         a.   When operated on a City street, an LSV shall have its headlight
and tail lamps lighted as required by 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/12-201.
         b.   A person shall not operate an LSV if he or she is impaired, such
as under the influence of alcohol or other drugs.
         c.   A person who operates an LSV must carry any vehicle insurance
required by State law. Documentation of valid insurance must be submitted to
the City at the time of initial registration of the vehicle and at the time of
permit renewal.
         d.   An owner or operator of an LSV must meet all other State and
local requirements.
      4.   Yearly Registration/Permit Requirements; Vehicle Inspection: A
person who intends to operate an LSV on Nauvoo streets and roadways shall first
have it inspected by the Chief of Police (or his designee) to determine whether
the operator and the vehicle have met all State and local requirements. He or
she then shall register it with the City and obtain a yearly permit for its
operation. The permit shall be visibly displayed on the slow moving vehicle
placard at the rear of the vehicle.
Vehicles are subject to re-inspection at any time at the discretion of the
Chief of Police or the City Council.
The LSV permit shall be valid from May 1 of the current year through April 30
of the following year. The annual permit fee, per vehicle, shall be set by the
City Council. The annual fee may be reviewed as needed and changed by a
majority vote of the City Council at any regular or special meeting.
      5.   Violations; Penalties: A violation of this subsection Q shall be
punishable by a fine of seventy five dollars ($75.00) for the first offense and
one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for the second offense in a 12-month
period. A person charged with a third offense in a 12-month period shall have
his or her permit permanently revoked and shall pay a fine of three hundred
dollars ($300.00).
   R.   Operation Of Certain Non-Highway Vehicles 2 : It shall be unlawful for
any person to operate a non-highway vehicle on any street or roadway within the
City of Nauvoo, except as expressly authorized in this subsection.
      1.   Definition Of Non-Highway Vehicle (NHV): As used here, a non-
highway vehicle is a motor vehicle that is not specifically designed to be used
on a public highway, including a golf cart 3  and a recreational off-highway
vehicle 4 . Although an all-terrain vehicle 5  and a recreational off-highway
motorcycle 6  are often included in that definition of NHVs, those types of
NHVs are not authorized to be operated on Nauvoo streets or roadways.
      2.   Restricted Streets: The NHV may be operated only on City streets and
roadways where the posted speed limit is thirty five (35) mph or less.
      3.   Restricted Crossing Of State Highway: A person operating a NHV may
cross a State highway (such as Mulholland Street) but may do so only at Parley
Street, Wilcox Street, and Bluff Street.
      4.   License Requirement: A person may not operate a NHV unless he or she
has a valid driver's license issued by the Secretary of State or by a foreign
jurisdiction.
      5.   Minimum Equipment Requirements: A NHV may not be operated within the
City limits unless the vehicle has the following equipment: brakes; a steering
apparatus; tires; a rearview mirror; red reflectorized warning devices in the
front and rear; a slow moving vehicle emblem on the rear of the vehicle 7 ; a
headlight that emits a white light visible from a distance of five hundred feet
(500') to the front; a tail lamp that emits a red light visible from at least
one hundred feet (100') from the rear; brake lights; turn signals; and seat
belts.
      6.   Miscellaneous Requirements:
         a.   An operator of a NHV must use seatbelts in accordance with 625
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/12-603.1 and 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 25/
1 et seq., and with any other applicable State laws.
         b.   When operated on a roadway, a NHV shall have its headlight and
tail lamps lighted as required by 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/12-201.
         c.   A person shall not operate a NHV if he or she is impaired, such
as under the influence of alcohol or other drugs.
         d.   A person who operates a NHV must carry any vehicle insurance
required by State law. Documentation of valid insurance must be submitted to
the City at the time of initial registration of the vehicle and at the time of
permit renewal.
      7.   Yearly Registration/Permit Requirements; Vehicle Inspection: A
person who intends to operate a NHV on Nauvoo streets and roadways shall first
have it inspected by the Chief of Police (or his designee) to determine whether
the operator and the vehicle have met all State and local requirements. He or
she then shall register it with the City and obtain a yearly permit for its
operation. The permit shall be visibly displayed on the slow moving vehicle
placard at the rear of the vehicle.
Vehicles are subject to re-inspection at any time at the discretion of the
Chief of Police or the City Council.
The NHV permit shall be valid from May 1 of the current year through April 30
of the following year. The annual permit fee, per vehicle, shall be set by the
City Council. The annual fee may be reviewed as needed and changed by a
majority vote of the City Council at any regular or special meeting.
      8.   Violations; Penalties: A violation of this subsection R shall be
punishable by a fine of seventy five dollars ($75.00) for the first offense and
one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for the second offense in a 12-month
period. A person charged with a third offense in a 12-month period shall have
his or her permit permanently revoked and shall pay a fine of three hundred
dollars ($300.00). (Ord. 2018-5, 9-11-2018)
 
Notes
1 1. This subsection Q is based upon 625 ILCS 5/11-1426.2, which relates to the
  operation of low-speed vehicles on streets.
2 1. This subsection R is based upon 625 ILCS 5/11-1426.1, which relates to the
  operation of non-highway vehicles on streets, roads, and highways.
3 2. As defined by 625 ILCS 5/1-123.9.
4 3. As defined by 625 ILCS 5/1-168.8.
5 4. As defined by 625 ILCS 5/1-101.8.
6 5. As defined by 625 ILCS 5/1-153.1.
7 1. As required of other vehicles in 625 ILCS 5/12-709.
9-1-3: DRIVING THROUGH PROCESSIONS:
No vehicle, as herein provided, shall be driven through a procession, except
with the permission of a police officer. (Ord. 129, 9-5-1916)
9-1-4: VEHICLES NOT TO OBSTRUCT TRAFFIC:
No vehicle shall be allowed to remain in, upon or be driven through any street
of the City so as to wilfully blockade or obstruct the said street. (Ord. 129,
9-5-1916)
9-1-5: AGE LIMITS FOR DRIVERS:
The allowable age for driving vehicles within the City limits, including
vehicles for hire, shall be the age set by the State of Illinois and/or the
Illinois Secretary of State. (Ord. 2013-6, 10-8-2013)
9-1-6: VEHICLE EQUIPMENT:
   A.   Every motor vehicle shall carry during the period from sunset to one
hour before sunrise at least two (2) lighted lamps, showing white lights
visible at least two hundred feet (200') in the direction toward which the
motor vehicle is proceeding. Such lights shall be dimmed or so arranged as not
to throw a blinding light in any direction. Every motor vehicle, except
motorcycles, shall also exhibit two (2) lighted lamps, which shall be so
situated as to throw a red light visible from the back of the vehicle. The
identification number at the back of the vehicle shall be permanently attached
to the vehicle so that it will not swing loosely and shall be so lighted as to
be plainly visible. Such lights shall be kept burning when any motor vehicle is
standing on any public street or alley. (Ord. 129, 9-5-1916; amd. 1989 Code)
   B.   Every automobile, motor vehicle or motorcycle, while being upon
streets, alleys and public places of the City, shall be provided with a
suitable brake; and shall be provided with a suitable bell or horn, or other
signal device; and it shall be unlawful for any person operating an automobile,
motor vehicle or motorcycle to make or cause to be made any loud or unnecessary
noise with any such bell, horn or other signal device, or to use such bell,
horn or other signal device, except as a warning of danger.
   C.   No person operating any automobile, motor vehicle or motorcycle shall
permit the pipes, "muffler" or other device to emit sounds of exhaust in a loud
and annoying manner, and all such automobiles, motor vehicles and motorcycles
shall be operated in as noiseless a manner as possible. No person operating any
automobile, motor vehicle or motorcycle shall permit the motor of the same to
operate in such a manner as to visibly emit an unduly great amount of steam,
smoke or products of combustion from exhaust pipes or openings. (Ord. 129, 9-5-
1916; amd. 1989 Code)
9-1-7: OBEYING OFFICERS AND TRAFFIC CONTROL SIGNS AND SIGNALS:
   A.   Drivers of vehicles must, at all times, comply with any direction, by
voice or hand, of any member of the police force, as to place, speed, or
stopping, starting, approaching, or pulling from any place, the manner of
taking out or setting down passengers or loading or unloading goods at any
place.
   B.   Drivers of vehicles must, at all times, comply with the instructions of
any traffic sign or signal placed in view by authority of the City Council or
in accordance with the laws of the State of Illinois. All signs established by
direction of the City Council shall conform to the State standards for traffic
signs or signals. (Ord. 1993-5, 1-11-1994)
9-1-8: SPEED LIMITS:
The rate of speed of motor vehicles and motorbikes, when operated upon any of
the public streets of the City, where the same pass through the closely built
up portion of the City, shall not exceed twenty five (25) miles per hour; or
where the street passes through the residence portion of the City, the rate of
speed shall not exceed thirty (30) miles per hour, except as posted; or where
the street passes through the Historical District of the City, the rate of
speed shall not exceed twenty (20) miles per hour, except as otherwise posted.
(Ord. 1993-5, 1-11-1994)
The rate of speed of motor vehicles and motor bicycles operated on Winchester
Street of the City shall not exceed thirty five (35) miles per hour. (Ord.
2002-11, 11-12-2002)
9-1-9: DRIVING IN CARELESS OR DISORDERLY MANNER:
   A.   It shall be unlawful, within the City limits, for any person operating
a motor vehicle to, at any time, spin, slide or squeal its tires in the
operation of such motor vehicle. For purposes of this section "squeal" is
defined as any audible noise caused by sliding or spinning tires. For purposes
of this section, a "motor vehicle" is any vehicle required to be licensed by
the State of Illinois. Any such conduct shall be known as disorderly conduct
and shall constitute a misdemeanor, and upon conviction be subject to a fine of
not less than one dollar ($1.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00).
   B.   It shall be unlawful, within the City limits, for any person operating
a motor vehicle to operate or drive such vehicle in a careless manner. For
purposes of this section, "careless driving" is defined as any driving in a
careless or negligent manner so as to unnecessarily or neglectfully endanger
life or property. For purposes of this section, a "motor vehicle" is any
vehicle required to be licensed by the State of Illinois. Any such conduct
shall be known as disorderly conduct and shall constitute a misdemeanor, and
upon conviction, be subject to a fine of not less than one dollar ($1.00) nor
more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). (Ord. 1978-1, 2-6-1978)
9-1-10: RACING AUTOMOBILES:
No racing by automobiles or trucks or motorcycles shall be allowed on any
street in the City, and any person who shall engage in any race with any motor
driven vehicle shall be guilty of an offense and, on conviction therefor, shall
forfeit and pay to the City not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than
one hundred dollars ($100.00). (Ord. 287, 11-5-1945; amd. 1989 Code; 1991)
9-1-11: ILLINOIS VEHICLE CODE ADOPTED:
The Illinois Vehicle Code 1 , as passed, approved, and amended from time to
time, is hereby adopted by the City. The provisions of the Illinois Vehicle
Code shall be controlling within the corporate limits of the City; however, the
penalties provided by this Code shall apply. (Ord. 2013-8, 2-11-2014)
 
Notes
1 1. 625 ILCS 5/1-100, et seq.
9-1-12: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the rules, regulations, or provisions of this
title, unless otherwise provided, shall be punished by a fine of not less than
fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than the maximum fine imposed by 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/1-2-1 (currently $750.00) per offense and may be required
to pay related fees and costs, including fees for the towing and/or storage of
towed or impounded vehicles. (Ord. 2013-8, 2-11-2014)
CHAPTER 2
PARKING REGULATIONS
SECTION:
9-2-1: Time Limit Parking
9-2-2: Loading And Unloading Zones
9-2-3: Parking For Handicapped Persons
9-2-4: No Parking
9-2-1: TIME LIMIT PARKING:
   A.   Fifteen Minute Parking: From and after the effective date of hereof, it
shall be unlawful for parking to occur for longer than a fifteen (15) minute
period at the following locations:
      The east side of Bluff Street, from the alley south of City Hall to
Knight Street, with the exception of two (2) parking stalls south of Knight
Street which are reserved for employee parking.
   The city shall place signs notifying the general public, in the area
described in this subsection, of the authorized parking areas, but the city may
cause to be placed yellow curb marking or some other type of markings
appropriate for safety.
   Violation of this subsection shall result in a thirty five dollar ($35.00)
fine being assessed against the person or persons found to have violated this
subsection, along with any and all allowable fees and court costs.
   B.   United States Post Office, Ten Minute Parking: Within thirty (30) days
after the effective date hereof, in accordance with law, the city shall place a
yellow curb marking or appropriate sign on Barnett Street, upon the side of the
street nearest to the entranceway of the United States post office, said yellow
curb marking or appropriate sign to continue for approximately forty feet (40')
as the city council shall direct.
   An appropriate number of signs or signals shall be placed as near to the
edge of such yellow curb marking that is practical, notifying the general
public that the area described between such signs and generally described by
the yellow marking upon the curb on Barnett Street shall authorize and permit
vehicular parking for ten (10) minutes only, per vehicle.
   From and after the date of such publication, it shall be unlawful for
parking to occur for longer than a ten (10) minute period in the area marked by
yellow curb marking and more fully described and designated between the
standing signs or signals referred to above.
   Violation of this subsection shall result in a twenty five dollar ($25.00)
fine being assessed against the person found to have violated this subsection
along with any and all necessary court costs therein.
   C.   One Hour Parking: From and after the effective date hereof, it shall be
unlawful for parking to occur for longer than a one hour period at the
following locations:
      On the west side of Bluff Street between Mulholland Street and Knight
Street.
      On the west side of Wells Street between Mulholland Street and Knight
Street.
   The city shall place signs notifying the general public in the area
described in this subsection one hour parking shall be authorized and allowed
per vehicle but the city may cause to be placed yellow curb marking or any
other type of marking appropriate for safety.
   Violation of this subsection shall result in a five dollar ($5.00) fine
being assessed against the person or persons found to have violated this
subsection along with any and all necessary court costs therein. (Ord. 1983,
10-3-1983; Ord. 1990-7, 3-12-1991; Ord. 2004-5, 7-13-2004; Ord. 2019-2, 7-9-
2019)
9-2-2: LOADING AND UNLOADING ZONES:
   A.   Authority: The city council may from time to time designate certain no
parking zones which shall be so designated for the express purpose of
authorizing the loading and unloading of products, wares or inventory, as the
case may be, with said no parking zones established adjacent to the city's
streets or highways, as shall be determined from time to time hereafter by the
chairman of the streets, buildings and grounds committee of the city council.
(Ord. 1985-1, 8-5-1985; amd. Ord. 2008-13, 4-28-2009)
   B.   Signs Posted: The city council may from time to time hereafter place
such markings, signs or other indication informing the general public as to the
location of the no parking zone as well as the times established for that no
parking zone, and further providing notice of penalty for failure to comply
with the terms and conditions of this section.
It shall be the duty of the city clerk to promptly notify the superintendent of
streets as to any areas designated as a no parking zone within the city limits.
The superintendent of streets shall then place an appropriate sign or other
indication of the no parking zone, in a clear and visible manner, which said
sign or other indication shall become immediately subject to the traffic laws
of the city or state of Illinois, as the case may be.
   C.   Violation And Penalties: It shall hereinafter be deemed a violation of
this section for any person to stop, stand or park a vehicle at any time
designated herein as a no parking zone, except when to avoid conflicts with
other traffic, or in compliance with the direction of the duly authorized
police officer or official traffic control device, or as otherwise permitted
herein. Any person who shall violate any provision of this section shall, in
addition to any other relief the law may afford, be subject to a punishment by
a fine of not more than fifty dollars ($50.00) or less than fifteen dollars
($15.00), and each day such violation is permitted to continue shall constitute
a separate offense, and any person violating a provision hereof shall promptly
be issued a citation or notice of violation charging such offense. Such
citation or notice of violation shall be in a form prescribed by the city
marshal and shall advise such person that a penalty for such violation may at
the discretion of such person be paid to the city clerk within seven (7) days
of the date of such citation or notice of violation. Such penalty shall be
fifteen dollars ($15.00) if so paid. In the event such penalty is timely paid,
that payment shall be in full satisfaction of any penalty for such violation.
In the event that such payment is not made within the time prescribed, a
complaint shall be initiated by the city marshal or other appropriate person or
by information initiated by the city attorney before a court of proper
jurisdiction charging such offense. (Ord. 1985-1, 8-5-1985)
9-2-3: PARKING FOR HANDICAPPED PERSONS:
   A.   Definition: For the purpose of this section, the term "handicapped
person" shall mean and include every natural person who has permanently lost
the use of a leg or both legs or an arm or both arms or any combination
thereof; is so severely disabled as to be unable to move without the aid of
crutches, wheelchair or prosthetics; because of old age, physical incapacity or
imperfection or deterioration is unable to move or walk without great
discomfort, or a physician duly licensed in the state of Illinois to practice
medicine or surgery in all of its branches has determined that said person
would benefit from being classified as a handicapped person under the
provisions of this section to relieve conditions resulting from old age,
physical incapacity or imperfection or deterioration.
   B.   Vehicle Requirements: A vehicle shall be designated as being operated
by or for a handicapped person if either of the conditions of this subsection
are complied with:
      1.   If such vehicle bears registration plates specified in paragraph 11-
1301.1 (pertaining to handicapped persons' parking exemptions), paragraph 3-609
(pertaining to disabled veterans), or paragraph 3-616 (pertaining to physically
handicapped persons), or other comparable provisions of the Illinois vehicle
code 1 .
      2.   Within the city, the Illinois vehicle code 2  shall be followed.
   C.   Parking Space Requirements: A parking space shall be designated as
being for a handicapped person if the conditions of this subsection are
complied with: (Ord. 2007-6, 9-11-2007)
      1.   The city council may from time to time designate parking spaces as
being parking spaces for handicapped person parking only. The chairman of the
streets, buildings and grounds committee of the city council or designee, in
his discretion, and when traffic conditions warrant, may further designate
specific parking spaces as being handicapped person parking only. Such parking
spaces designated as herein provided shall be on property under the control and
jurisdiction of the city, including, but not limited to, streets, alleys and
parking lots. All of such parking spaces shall be referred to as general
handicapped person parking spaces. (Ord. 2007-6, 9-11-2007; amd. Ord. 2008-13,
4-28-2009)
      2.   The owner or owners of real property which is regularly used by the
public for purposes of vehicular travel by permission of the owner or owners
shall, from time to time, designate specific parking spaces on such real
property as being parking spaces for handicapped person parking only. All such
parking spaces shall also be referred to as general handicapped person parking
spaces and shall comply with section
10-3-7 of this code.
      3.   Restricted parking for handicapped persons may from time to time be
established as herein provided. All such restricted parking shall be restricted
to or for the use of the specific handicapped person or persons designated when
established, under the following conditions: (Ord. 2007-6, 9-11-2007)
         a.   Any person who owns or operates a vehicle designated pursuant to
the provisions herein, may apply for a parking space restricted to parking for
or by a designated handicapped person or persons only. Such application shall
be filed with the city clerk (and may be filed in conjunction with an
application for a handicapped person sticker as provided hereinabove). The
application, upon receipt, shall be reviewed by the chairman of the streets,
buildings and grounds committee, or his designee, to determine whether the
designation of a restricted parking space would adversely affect traffic
conditions in the city or be contrary to the traffic laws of the city or the
state of Illinois.
         b.   In the event the city clerk determines the application is in
proper form and the chairman of the streets, buildings and grounds committee,
or his designee, determines that a restricted parking space would not adversely
affect traffic conditions in the city or would not be contrary to the traffic
conditions in the city or would not be contrary to the traffic laws of the city
or the state of Illinois, a restricted parking space shall be established. All
such parking spaces shall be referred to as restricted handicapped person
parking spaces. (Ord. 2007-6, 9-11-2007; amd. Ord. 2008-13, 4-28-2009)
         c.   All restricted parking spaces established hereunder shall be
limited to spaces immediately in front of and adjacent to real property owned
or occupied by the handicapped person or persons.
         d.   The city clerk shall promptly notify the superintendent of
streets of any restricted parking spaces established. The superintendent shall
place an appropriate sign at such location noting that such space is parking
for or by a designated handicapped person or persons only.
         e.   A fee equal to the cost of the sign and labor shall be charged
for the placement of a restricted parking sign as provided herein.
         f.   Any restricted parking spaces established hereunder shall
terminate automatically when the appropriate person's vehicle is no longer
designated as provided above.
   D.   Parking In Spaces For The Handicapped:
      1.   No persons shall stop, stand or park a vehicle at any time
designated herein as parking for handicapped persons, except when necessary to
avoid conflicts with other traffic, or in compliance with the direction of the
duly authorized police officer or official traffic control device, or as
otherwise permitted herein.
      2.   A person may stop, stand or park a vehicle at any place designated
as a general handicapped person parking space provided such vehicle bears valid
registration plates or a handicapped person sticker as provided for in this
section. Such registration plates or stickers shall not entitle a person to
stop, stand or park a vehicle in a restricted handicapped person parking space
for handicapped persons unless such space has been designated for that person.
      3.   A person may stop, stand or park a vehicle at a place designated for
that person as a restricted handicapped person parking space.
   E.   Sign Specifications: Insofar as is practical, signs utilized hereunder
shall conform with the most recent edition of the national "Manual On Uniform
Traffic Control Devices" for streets and highways. Restricted handicapped
person parking signs, however, may simply include the words "Restricted Parking
by Permit Only", without further designation.
   F.   Penalties: Any person who shall violate any provision of this section
shall, in addition to any other relief the law may afford, be subject to a
punishment by a fine in the amount described in the Illinois vehicle code 3
and each day such violation is permitted to continue shall constitute a
separate offense. Any person violating a provision hereof shall promptly be
issued a citation or notice of violation charging such offense. Such citation
or notice of violation shall be in a form prescribed by the city marshal and
shall advise such person that a penalty for such violation may at the
discretion of such person be paid to the city clerk within seven (7) days of
the date of such citation or notice of violation. Such penalty shall be five
hundred dollars ($500.00) if not so paid. In the event such penalty is timely
paid, that payment shall be in full satisfaction of any penalty for such
violation. In the event that such payment is not made within the time period
prescribed, a complaint shall be initiated by the city marshal or other
appropriate person or by information initiated by the city attorney before a
court of proper jurisdiction charging such offense.
   G.   Fraudulent Use: Use of handicap placard or plates shall comply with the
Illinois vehicle code 4 . (Ord. 2007-6, 9-11-2007)
 
Notes
1 1. 625 ILCS.
2 2. 625 ILCS.
3 1. 625 ILCS 5/11-1301.3.
4 2. 625 ILCS 5/11-1301.3.
9-2-4: NO PARKING:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to park any
motor vehicle within the areas indicated below:
      1.   Durphy Street, from the south city limit northerly to the
intersection with Mulholland Street, except for the following, where parallel
parking is allowed:
         On the west side of Durphy Street from 4.57 meters (15 feet) south of
the south edge of pavement of Hotchkiss Street at the intersection of Hotchkiss
Street and Durphy Street southerly 33.22 meters (109 feet) and from 4.57 meters
(15 feet) south of the south edge of pavement of White Street at the
intersection of White Street and Durphy Street southerly 24.38 meters (80
feet).
      2.   Mulholland Street, from the westernmost boundary at Main Street,
easterly to the east city limit, except for the following where parallel
parking is allowed:
         On the north side of Mulholland Street from the intersection with
Wells Street easterly to the intersection with Barnett Street and from 7.62
meters (25 feet) east of the east edge of pavement of Barnett Street easterly
57.91 meters (190 feet); and
         On the south side of Mulholland Street from 54.9 meters (180 feet)
west of the west edge of pavement of Bluff Street easterly to 7.62 meters (25
feet) west of the west edge of pavement of Bluff Street and from the
intersection of Bluff Street easterly to the intersection with Barnett Street
and from 7.62 meters (25 feet) east of the east edge of Barnett Street easterly
36.58 meters (120 feet).
      3.   Mulholland Street, from Durphy Street to Main Street (in order to
accommodate truck and bus traffic).
      4.   Bluff Street, from the north side of the intersection at Knight
Street to the south side of the intersection at Young Street - no parking on
the east side of the street only.
      5.   Bluff Street, from Mulholland Street to Ripley Street.
      6.   Parley Street, from the west side adjoining Water Street to Hwy 96
(in order to accommodate bus routes).
      7.   White Street, from Main Street to Durphy Street (in order to
accommodate truck and bus traffic).
      8.   Hotchkiss Street, from Main Street to Durphy Street (in order to
accommodate truck and bus traffic).
      9.   Hubbard Street, from Durphy Street to Wells Street (in order to
accommodate truck and bus traffic).
      10.   Knight Street, between Fulmer Street and Gordon Street (in order to
accommodate truck and bus traffic).
      11.   Knight Street, from Bluff Street to Wells Street - no parking on
the north side of the street except during church times and during funerals; no
parking at any time on the south side of the street.
      12.   Main Street, from White Street to Broadway Street (in order to
accommodate truck and bus traffic).
      13.   Warsaw Street, from Mulholland to Knight Street - no parking on the
east side of the street only.
      14.   Iowa Street, from 160 feet north of Mulholland Street to Knight
Street - no parking on the east side of the street only.
      15.   Wells Street, from Cutler Street to Hubbard Street.
      16.   Wells Street, from Knight Street to Young Street - no parking on
both sides of the street except during church times and during funerals.
Parking is allowed in front of the church only where posted.
      17.   Wells Street, from Mulholland Street to Knight Street - no parking
on the east side except for the ten (10) minute loading/unloading zone located
in front of the Nauvoo Temple.
      18.   Fulmer Street, from Mulholland Street to Ripley Street.
      19.   At any other location, pursuant to the authority of the Mayor or
Nauvoo Police Department, where parking may be temporarily or permanently
restricted (or allowed) due to an emergency, natural disaster, special event,
or some other special circumstance.
   B.   Any person, firm or corporation violating the provisions of this
section shall be fined not less than thirty five dollars ($35.00) nor more than
fifty dollars ($50.00) for each offense. (Ord., 11-13-1996; Ord. 2019-2, 7-9-
2019)
CHAPTER 3
BICYCLES
SECTION:
9-3-1: Licensing Requirements
9-3-2: Registration Transfer
9-3-3: Lost License
9-3-4: Alteration Of License Tag
9-3-5: Lights Required
9-3-6: Parking Bicycles
9-3-7: Riding On Sidewalks
9-3-8: Rights Of Pedestrians
9-3-9: Single File Riding
9-3-10: Observance Of Traffic Rules
9-3-11: Towing Unlawful
9-3-12: Extra Passengers
9-3-13: Out Of Proportion Bicycles
9-3-14: Improper Riding
9-3-15: Penalties
9-3-1: LICENSING REQUIREMENTS:
Every person who is a resident of or lives within the city limits who owns a
bicycle shall cause the ownership thereof to be registered with the city clerk.
Registration by citizens of Nauvoo sixteen (16) years of age or older will
receive a license/registration tag at no cost upon presenting a valid driver's
license to the city clerk.
Other citizens of Nauvoo will receive a registration tag at no charge upon
passing a written exam from the Illinois department of transportation "bicycles
rules of the road", that will exhibit knowledge of road signs and basic bicycle
operating rules, or by participation in a bicycle safety program approved by
the Nauvoo city marshal. (Ord. 1990-2, 7-10-1990)
9-3-2: REGISTRATION TRANSFER:
Upon the sale or transfer of the licensed bicycle, the original license tag
shall be transferred to the new owner or transferee, and the sale or transfer
shall be reported to the city clerk within five (5) days of the sale or
transfer. The city clerk shall note the transfer in records to be kept at the
city clerk's office. (Ord. 1990-2, 7-10-1990)
9-3-3: LOST LICENSE:
In the event the license tag is lost, destroyed, stolen, or no longer able to
remain affixed to said bicycle, the city clerk shall issue a new license tag to
the existing owner, at a fee of one dollar ($1.00) payable to the city clerk.
(Ord. 1990-2, 7-10-1990)
9-3-4: ALTERATION OF LICENSE TAG:
It shall be unlawful and a violation of this chapter for any person to alter,
damage, destroy or counterfeit any license tag issued under this chapter. (Ord.
1990-2, 7-10-1990)
9-3-5: LIGHTS REQUIRED:
All bicycles used within the city limits shall, during the hours from sunset
until sunrise display a headlight on the forward part of the bicycle visible
from a distance of at least three hundred feet (300'), said headlight to be
stationary and securely affixed to the bicycle. There shall also be displayed
on the rear part of the bicycle a red reflector not to be smaller than one and
one- half inches (11/2") in diameter or a red light of similar size. (Ord.
1990-2, 7-10-1990)
9-3-6: PARKING BICYCLES:
A bicycle parked on a sidewalk shall not impede the normal and reasonable
movement of pedestrian or other traffic. (Ord. 1990-02, 7-10-1990)
9-3-7: RIDING ON SIDEWALKS:
A person propelling a bicycle upon and along a sidewalk, or across a roadway,
upon and along a crosswalk shall yield the right of way to any pedestrian and
shall give audible signal before overtaking and passing such pedestrian. (Ord.
1990-2, 7-10-1990)
9-3-8: RIGHTS OF PEDESTRIANS:
Pedestrians upon sidewalks shall have the right of way at all times over
persons using or operating bicycles upon any sidewalk not herein prohibited,
and any person using or operating a bicycle upon any sidewalk shall turn off
the sidewalk at all times when meeting or passing pedestrians. (Ord. 1990-2, 7-
10-1990)
9-3-9: SINGLE FILE RIDING:
Bicycles shall be ridden in single file in the business district. Bicycles may
be ridden two (2) abreast in residential districts, but no person or persons
shall ride more than two (2) abreast upon any street or sidewalk located within
the city. Bicycles shall be operated as near to the right curb of any street as
possible at all times. (Ord. 1990-2, 7-10-1990)
9-3-10: OBSERVANCE OF TRAFFIC RULES:
All persons using or operating bicycles upon any street or sidewalk within the
city shall observe all traffic rules as to traffic lights and stop signs and
shall signal any change of direction or course of traffic in the same manner as
such signals are required under the law governing the use of motor vehicles
upon streets and highways of this state. (Ord. 1990-2, 7-10-1990)
9-3-11: TOWING UNLAWFUL:
It is unlawful for any person riding a bicycle to be towed or to tow any other
vehicle upon the streets of the city. It is also unlawful for any person riding
a bicycle to follow a fire truck or other fire equipment at any time. (Ord.
1990-2, 7-10-1990)
9-3-12: EXTRA PASSENGERS:
Only one person shall ride a bicycle at one time and extra passengers shall not
be carried upon a bicycle at any time; provided, however, this section shall
not apply to a person riding upon a bicycle which has been constructed to carry
two (2) people, and shall not be construed to apply to a person who has reached
the age of majority who is riding a bicycle with a child seated upon a suitable
device constructed and designed for the specific purpose of carrying a child.
(Ord. 1990-2, 7-10-1990)
9-3-13: OUT OF PROPORTION BICYCLES:
It is unlawful for any person to ride a bicycle designed or constructed in such
proportions as to make it unwieldy or hazardous to operate under all known
conditions except when the bicycle is operated in a city approved parade, show
or exhibition. (Ord. 1990-2, 7-10-1990)
9-3-14: IMPROPER RIDING:
It is unlawful for any person riding a bicycle within the corporate limits of
the city to ride in an irregular or reckless manner, including, but not limited
to, zigzagging, speeding, or otherwise riding with disregard for either the
operator's safety or the safety of others. No person shall ride a bicycle
across the private property of another in such a manner as to cause damage to
said property. (Ord. 1990-2, 7-10-1990)
9-3-15: PENALTIES:
   A.   Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a
violation of said chapter, except registration. A violation of the registration
provisions of this chapter shall cause a written warning citation to be issued
to the violator.
   B.   Any person violating any provision of this chapter a second time,
except registration, will receive a written citation and be assessed a ten
dollar ($10.00) fine, and the violator's bicycle may be impounded for one to
ten (10) days.
   C.   Any person violating this chapter for a third time, except
registration, will receive a written citation under the Illinois vehicle code 1
.
   D.   Any person violating the registration section of this chapter will
receive a warning citation for the first offense.
   E.   Any person violating the registration section of this chapter will
receive a written citation and be assessed a five dollar ($5.00) fine for every
offense thereafter.
   F.   Any rental bicycle impounded under this chapter may be picked up
immediately at city hall by the registered owner or owner's representative.
   G.   Any nonresident person violating a section of this chapter will receive
a written warning citation.
   H.   Any nonresident person violating a section of this chapter as a second
offense will have the bicycle impounded until such person is prepared to depart
the city or by being assessed a ten dollar ($10.00) fine.
   I.   Any bicycle left impounded for thirty (30) days will be considered city
property and available for the most economic means of disposal, including sale
or disposal. (Ord. 1990-2, 7-10-1990)
 
Notes
1 1. 625 ILCS.
CHAPTER 4
TRUCK ROUTE
SECTION:
9-4-1: Definitions
9-4-2: Use Required
9-4-3: Trucks On Other Streets Prohibited
9-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and phrases when used in this chapter shall have the
meanings respectively assigned to them by 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-
100 et seq., otherwise known as the Illinois vehicle code, as may be amended
from time to time:
   Apportionable semitrailer,
   Apportionable trailer,
   Road tractor, and
   Truck tractor.
Hereinafter, for simplicity, the above terms shall be referred to as "truck" or
"trucks". (Ord. 2000-3, 2-13-2001)
9-4-2: USE REQUIRED:
Trucks shall be permitted only on designated truck routes as set forth on the
truck route map in this section and as described below:
   Main Street from Hotchkiss to Broadway Street;
   Broadway Street;
   Mulholland Street to Main Street;
   State highway;
   White Street from Main Street to state highway;
   Parley Street from state highway to Winchester Street;
   Winchester Street from state highway to Parley Street;
   Young Street from Main Street to Wells Street;
   Durphy Street from Young Street to Cutler Street;
   Cutler Street from Durphy Street to Wells Street;
   Wells Street from Young Street to Cutler Street;
   Hotchkiss Street from state highway to Main Street.

9-4-3: TRUCKS ON OTHER STREETS PROHIBITED:

CHAPTER 5
BUS ROUTE
SECTION:
9-5-1: Definitions
9-5-2: Use Required
9-5-3: Buses On Other Streets Prohibited
9-5-4: Engines Running
9-5-5: Penalty
9-5-6: Enforcement
9-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and phrases when used in this chapter shall have the
meanings respectively assigned to them by 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-
100 et seq., otherwise known as the Illinois vehicle code, as may be amended
from time to time:
   Bus, and
   Recreational vehicle.
Hereinafter, for simplicity, the above terms shall be referred to as "bus" or
"buses". (Ord. 2000-12, 5-8-2001)

route map in this section and described as follows:

All of Water Street;

Robinson Street for 150 feet south of Mulholland Street;

9-5-4: ENGINES RUNNING:

CHAPTER 7
INOPERABLE AND UNLICENSED VEHICLES
SECTION:
9-7-1: Definitions
9-7-2: Inoperable Motor Vehicle
9-7-3: Unlicensed Motor Vehicle
9-7-4: Motor Vehicle Component Parts
9-7-5: Exemptions
9-7-6: Removal
9-7-7: Authorized Removal
9-7-8: Sale Of Vehicle
9-7-9: Proceeds Of Sale
9-7-10: Liability For Damage
9-7-11: Penalties
9-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them as follows:
ANTIQUE VEHICLE: A motor vehicle that is more than twenty five (25) years of
age or a bona fide replica thereof, or a fire- fighting vehicle more than
twenty (20) years old that is not used as fire-fighting equipment but is used
only for the purpose of exhibition or demonstration.
INOPERABLE MOTOR VEHICLE: Any motor vehicle from which the engine, wheels, or
other parts have been removed, or on which the engine, wheels, or other parts
have been altered, damaged, or otherwise treated that the vehicle is incapable
of being driven under its own motor power, whether or not licensed.
MOTOR VEHICLES: Every vehicle that is self-propelled, including tractors,
dozers, machinery and equipment, except for vehicles moved solely by human or
animal power and except for motorized wheelchairs.
UNLICENSED MOTOR VEHICLES: Any motor vehicle that does not exhibit a current,
unexpired license or sticker from the State of Illinois or from any other
state. Unlicensed motor vehicles include automobiles, trucks, and motorcycles
or motorized cycles.
VEHICLE: Every device, in, upon, or by which any person, property, or material
or substance is or may be transported, pushed or drawn upon land, except
devices moved solely by human or animal power, and devices used exclusively
upon stationary rails or tracks. (Ord. 2013-8, 2-11-2014)
9-7-2: INOPERABLE MOTOR VEHICLE:
It is unlawful to store any inoperable motor vehicle on private property within
the City for a period of more than seven (7) days unless it is stored within an
enclosed building or is covered with a cover specifically designed to fit the
make and model of that vehicle. (Ord. 2013-8, 2-11-2014)
9-7-3: UNLICENSED MOTOR VEHICLE:
It is unlawful to store any unlicensed motor vehicle on private property within
the City for a period of more than seven (7) days unless it is stored within an
enclosed building or is covered with a cover specifically designed to fit the
make and model of that vehicle. (Ord. 2013-8, 2-11-2014)
9-7-4: MOTOR VEHICLE COMPONENT PARTS:
It is unlawful to store any motor vehicle component parts on private property
within the City for a period of more than seven (7) days unless they are stored
within an enclosed building and out of public view. (Ord. 2013-8, 2-11-2014)
9-7-5: EXEMPTIONS:
A motor vehicle that is classified or registered as an antique vehicle is
exempt from the provisions of this chapter, as are new and used car dealerships
that are duly licensed by the State of Illinois. Automotive repair facilities
licensed by the City shall have thirty (30) days, rather than seven (7) days,
to remove abandoned vehicles, unlicensed vehicles, inoperable vehicles, and
vehicle component parts from its property. (Ord. 2013-8, 2-11-2014)
9-7-6: REMOVAL:
The abandonment of a motor vehicle or any part of one on any roadway in the
City is unlawful and is subject to the penalties of this chapter. Any
unlicensed vehicle, inoperable vehicle, or motor vehicle component part located
on public or private property, which has been abandoned and is in view of the
general public, is unlawful and may be removed by the City of Nauvoo or upon
the order of the City's Chief of Police, if it has not been removed by its
owner within seven (7) days of the date that City personnel first discovered
it. (Ord. 2013-8, 2-11-2014)
9-7-7: AUTHORIZED REMOVAL:
   A.   When an abandoned, unattended, wrecked, burned, or partially dismantled
motor vehicle or some other type of vehicle is creating a traffic hazard
because of its position in relation to the roadway, or because its physical
appearance is impeding of traffic, the City's Chief of Police may order its
immediate removal from the roadway by a towing service.
   B.   When a motor vehicle or some other vehicle is removed from either
public or private property as authorized by order of the Chief of Police, the
owner of the vehicle is responsible for, and shall pay, all towing and storage
costs. (Ord. 2013-8, 2-11-2014)
9-7-8: SALE OF VEHICLE:
Whenever an abandoned, lost, stolen, or unclaimed motor vehicle or other type
of vehicle that is seven (7) years old or newer remains unclaimed by the
registered owner or other person legally entitled to its possession for a
period of thirty (30) days, and the owner or legal possessor has been given
notice, the Police Department having possession of the vehicle shall cause it
to be sold by private or public sale.
Notice of the time and place of the sale shall be posted in a conspicuous place
for at least ten (10) days before the sale at the premises where the vehicle
has been impounded. At least ten (10) days before the sale, the Police
Department, shall cause a notice of the time and place of the sale to be sent
by certified mail to the registered owner or to any other person known by the
Police Department or towing service to be legally entitled to possession of the
vehicle. Such notice shall contain a complete description of the vehicle to be
sold and what steps must be taken by any legally entitled person to reclaim the
vehicle.
In those instances where the certified mail notice has been returned to the
Police Department because of the addressee having moved, because the mail was
unclaimed or refused, or if a forwarding address is unknown, the sending of a
second notice by certified mail is not required.
When a motor vehicle that is more than seven (7) years old is impounded as
specified in this chapter, it will be kept in custody for a minimum of ten (10)
days for the purpose of determining ownership, contacting the registered owner
by U.S. mail or in person to determine disposition, and examining the Illinois
State Police stolen motor vehicle files for evidence of theft and other
information. At the expiration of the ten-day period, without the benefit of
disposition information or directions received from the registered owner, the
Chief of Police may authorize the disposal of the vehicle as a junk vehicle.
(Ord. 2013-8, 2-11-2014)
9-7-9: PROCEEDS OF SALE:
When a vehicle located within the City limits has been authorized by the Police
Chief to be towed and disposed of as set forth in this chapter, the proceeds of
the sale remaining after the payment of towing, storage, and processing fees
shall be deposited in the Police General Fund. (Ord. 2013-8, 2-11-2014)
9-7-10: LIABILITY FOR DAMAGE:
Any police officer, towing service, owner/operator, or employee shall not be
held liable for damages in any claim asserted by, or action filed by, the
registered owner, former registered owner, or other person legally entitled to
possession of that vehicle when the vehicle was disposed of pursuant to the
requirements of this chapter. (Ord. 2013-8, 2-11-2014)
9-7-11: PENALTIES:
Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of an
offense and shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more
than the maximum fine imposed by 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-2-1
(currently $750.00) for each offense; each day that a violation exists or
continues shall constitute a separate offense. In addition to payment of the
required fine, the violator shall pay all fees related to the towing and
storage of the vehicle. The current storage fee is twenty dollars ($20.00) per
day, but that fee may be changed from time to time by a majority vote of the
City Council.
The person who violates this chapter also may be charged with violating the
City's Nuisance Code, and the nuisance may be abated as provided for in this
Code. (Ord. 2013-8, 2-11-2014)
CHAPTER 8
IMPOUNDED VEHICLES
SECTION:
9-8-1: Authority To Adopt Procedure And Fees; Fee Waiver
9-8-2: Violations Subject To Imposition Of Fees
9-8-3: Administrative Fee; Towing And Storage Charges
9-8-4: Impoundment Procedure
9-8-5: Notice Of Administrative Hearing
9-8-6: Administrative Hearing; Rules
9-8-7: Abandonment Of Impounded Vehicle; Sale
9-8-8: No Liability For Damage
9-8-9: Recovery Of Fees And Charges
9-8-1: AUTHORITY TO ADOPT PROCEDURE AND FEES; FEE WAIVER:
Pursuant to State law 1 , the City of Nauvoo hereby adopts the procedures set
forth in this chapter for the release of properly impounded vehicles and for
the imposition of a reasonable administrative fee related to the administrative
and processing costs associated with its investigation, arrest, and detention
of an offender or its removal, impoundment, storage, and release of the
vehicle. That administrative fee may be in addition to any fees charged for the
towing and storage of an impounded vehicle. However, the administrative fee
will be waived upon verifiable proof that the vehicle was stolen at the time
the vehicle was impounded. (Ord. 2014-8, 3-10-2015)
 
Notes
1 1. 625 ILCS 5/11-208.7.
9-8-2: VIOLATIONS SUBJECT TO IMPOSITION OF FEES:
Fees may be imposed for the following violations:
   A.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the
attempt to commit, an offense for which a motor vehicle may be seized and
forfeited pursuant to section 36-1 of the Criminal Code of 2012; or
   B.   Driving under the influence of alcohol, another drug or drugs, an
intoxicating compound or compounds, or any combination thereof, in violation of
625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-501; or
   C.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the
attempt to commit, a felony or in violation of the Cannabis Control Act; or
   D.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the
attempt to commit, an offense in violation of the Illinois Controlled
Substances Act; or
   E.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the
attempt to commit, an offense in violation of section 24-1, 24-1.5, or 24-3.1
of the Criminal Code of 1961 or the Criminal Code of 2012; or
   F.   Driving while a driver's license, permit, or privilege to operate a
motor vehicle is suspended or revoked pursuant to section 625 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/6-303, except that vehicles shall not be subjected to seizure or
impoundment if the suspension is for an unpaid citation (parking or moving) or
due to failure to comply with emission testing;
   G.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle while soliciting, possessing, or
attempting to solicit or possess, cannabis or a controlled substance, as
defined by the Cannabis Control Act or the Illinois Controlled Substances Act;
or
   H.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle with an expired driver's license,
in violation of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-101, if the period of
expiration is greater than one (1) year; or
   I.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle without ever having been issued a
driver's license or permit, in violation of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-
101, or operating a motor vehicle without ever having been issued a driver's
license or permit due to a person's age; or
   J.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle by a person against whom a warrant
has been issued by a Circuit Clerk in Illinois for failing to answer charges
that the driver violated 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-101, 6-303, or 11-
501;
   K.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the
attempt to commit, an offense in violation of article 16 or 16A of the Criminal
Code of 1961 or the Criminal Code of 2012; or
   L.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the
attempt to commit, any other misdemeanor or felony offense in violation of the
Criminal Code of 1961 or the Criminal Code of 2012, when so provided by City
ordinance; or
   M.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle in violation of 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/11-503:
      1.   While the vehicle is part of a funeral procession; or
      2.   In a manner that interferes with a funeral procession. (Ord. 2014-8,
3-10-2015)
9-8-3: ADMINISTRATIVE FEE; TOWING AND STORAGE CHARGES:
   A.   The administrative fee is currently set at two hundred dollars
($200.00) but may be changed from time to time by the City Council as
necessary.
   B.   All administrative fees and towing and storage charges shall be imposed
on the registered owner of the motor vehicle or the agents of that owner.
   C.   The administrative fee shall be in addition to any other penalties that
may be assessed by a court of law for the underlying violations and any towing
or storage fees, or both, charged by the towing company.
   D.   The administrative fee shall be uniform for all similarly situated
vehicles.
   E.   The administrative fee shall be collected by, and paid to, the City of
Nauvoo.
   F.   The towing or storage fees, or both, shall be collected by, and paid
to, the person, firm, or entity that tows and stores the impounded vehicle.
   G.   An impounded vehicle may be released to the owner of record, a lessee,
or a lien holder of record only after payment of all administrative fees and
towing and storage charges. (Ord. 2014-8, 3-10-2015)
9-8-4: IMPOUNDMENT PROCEDURE:
Whenever a police officer has cause to believe that a motor vehicle is subject
to impoundment, the officer shall provide for the towing of the vehicle to a
facility authorized by the City of Nauvoo.
At the time the vehicle is towed, the City of Nauvoo shall notify, or shall
make a reasonable attempt to notify, the owner, lessee, or person identifying
himself or herself as the owner or lessee of the vehicle, or any person who is
found to be in control of the vehicle at the time of the alleged offense, of
the fact of the seizure and of the vehicle owner's or lessee's right to an
administrative hearing.
The notice shall state that the motor vehicle will remain impounded pending the
completion of an administrative hearing, unless the owner or lessee of the
vehicle, or a lien holder, posts a bond with the City in an amount equal to the
administrative fee and pays for all towing and storage charges. (Ord. 2014-8,
3-10-2015)
9-8-5: NOTICE OF ADMINISTRATIVE HEARING:
The registered owner or lessee of the vehicle, and any lien holder of record,
shall be provided with notice of the administrative hearing. The notice of
hearing:
   A.   Shall be served upon the owner, lessee, and any lien holder of record
either by personal service or by first class mail sent to the interested
party's address as registered with the Secretary of State;
   B.   Shall be served upon the interested parties within ten (10) days after
a vehicle is impounded; and
   C.   Shall contain the date, time, and location of the administrative
hearing, which must be scheduled and convened no later than forty five (45)
days after the service date or mailing date of the notice. (Ord. 2014-8, 3-10-
2015)
9-8-6: ADMINISTRATIVE HEARING; RULES:
The administrative hearing shall be conducted as follows:
   A.   The administrative hearing shall be conducted by a Hearing Officer who
is an attorney licensed to practice law in this State for a minimum of three
(3) years.
   B.   Pursuant to 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-208.3(b)(4), the formal
or technical rules of evidence shall not apply during the hearing. The hearing
shall be recorded. The person conducting the hearing shall be empowered to
administer oaths and to secure by subpoena both the attendance and testimony of
witnesses and the production of relevant books and papers. Persons who appear
at the hearing may be represented by counsel at their own expense.
   C.   At the conclusion of the hearing, the Hearing Officer shall issue a
written decision, either sustaining or overruling the vehicle impoundment, and
a copy of the written decision shall be served upon the owner, lessee, and any
lien holder of record either by personal service or by first class mail sent to
the interested party's address as registered with the Secretary of State.
   D.   If the basis for the impoundment is sustained, any administrative fee
posted to secure the release of the vehicle shall be forfeited to the City.
   E.   All final decisions of the Administrative Hearing Officer shall be
subject to review under the provisions of the Administrative Review Law.
   F.   Unless the Administrative Hearing Officer overturns the basis for the
impoundment, no vehicle shall be released until all administrative fees and
towing and storage charges are paid. (Ord. 2014-8, 3-10-2015)
9-8-7: ABANDONMENT OF IMPOUNDED VEHICLE; SALE:
If an impounded vehicle is not retrieved from the towing or storage facility
within thirty five (35) days after the Administrative Hearing Officer issues a
written decision, it shall be deemed abandoned and may be disposed of by the
City by private or public sale. The proceeds of the sale shall be deposited in
the Police General Fund. (Ord. 2014-8, 3-10-2015)
9-8-8: NO LIABILITY FOR DAMAGE:
The City of Nauvoo, or any employee or agent, shall not be held liable for
damages in any claim asserted by, or action filed by, the registered owner,
lessee, or other person legally entitled to possession of the impounded vehicle
when the vehicle was disposed of pursuant to the requirements of this chapter.
(Ord. 2014-8, 3-10-2015)
9-8-9: RECOVERY OF FEES AND CHARGES:
Unless they are stayed by a court, any fees and charges imposed under this
chapter which remain unpaid in whole or in part after the expiration of the
deadline for seeking review of the administrative decision may be enforced in
the same manner as a judgment entered by a court of competent jurisdiction.
(Ord. 2014-8, 3-10-2015)
